column45:
Guidelines:

1. Eligibility:

  • Open to all college students from any institution.
  • Inter-college participation is permitted.
  • Students from any year and any department can participate.
  • Participation can be individual or in teams of two.

2. Team Formation:

  • Individual entries are allowed.
  • Maximum 2 members per team.
  • Inter-college and inter-department teams are allowed.

3. Event Format:

Phase 1 — Briefing (9:30 AM – 10:00 AM):

  • Instructions will be given.
  • Problem statement will be released on January 5.

Phase 2 — UI/UX Design (10:00 AM – 11:00 AM):

  • Understanding the brief.
  • Sketching / wireframing.
  • Designing using any of the allowed tools:
  • Figma
  • Adobe Illustrator
  • Canva
  • Photoshop
  • Paper sketches

Phase 3 — Website Build (11:00 AM – 2:00 PM):

  • Converting the UI into a functional website.
  • Allowed technologies:
  • HTML
  • CSS
  • (Optional) Basic JavaScript
  • No backend required.

Continuous Evaluation:

Judges will assess throughout the event based on:

  • Workflow
  • Design thinking
  • Coding approach
  • Team collaboration
  • Problem-solving process

4. Event Schedule:

  • Date: January 5
  • Time: 9:30 AM – 2:30 PM
  • Total Duration: 5 hours
  • Participants must report by 9:00 AM.

5. Facilities Provided:

  • Internet access
  • Workspace with power supply
  • Participants must bring their own laptop and charger.

Competition Rules: 

1. General Rules:

  • All work must be completed within the event duration.
  • No pre-made UI designs or website templates allowed.
  • All designs and code must be created on the event day.

2. Design Rules:

  • UI/UX must be completely self-created.
  • AI is NOT allowed for any design-related tasks.
  • Only the allowed design tools may be used.

3. Coding Rules:

  • Coding must be done using:
  • HTML
  • CSS
  • (Optional) Basic JavaScript

AI Usage (Strict Rules):

Allowed (for code only):

  • Code generation
  • Code reference
  • Debugging
  • Syntax help

Not allowed:

  • AI-generated UI designs
  • AI-generated design assets
  • Entire AI-generated websites

4. Submission Rules:

  • Submission deadline: 2:30 PM (strict).
  • Late submissions will not be accepted.
  • Teams must give a 2-minute explanation of their design and website.

5. Judging Criteria:

  • UX clarity and flow
  • UI design quality
  • Code structure and cleanliness
  • Creativity and originality
  • Completeness of the website
  • Performance during continuous evaluation

column45:
About the Magazine:

Consulere, the Consulting Club of the Department of Management Studies, IIT Delhi, proudly presents the inaugural edition of its Annual Consulting Magazine. As a club, we strive to foster deeper knowledge, curiosity, and real-world understanding of the consulting landscape. Through our year-round initiatives — including case competitions, sector ledgers, and our annual casebook — we aim to build a vibrant problem-solving community.
This first edition of our magazine seeks to bring together the finest opinions and insights of students across the country, covering a diverse range of strategic, managerial, and industry-focused themes. With this publication, we hope to create a platform that celebrates analytical depth, fresh perspectives, and the spirit of consulting excellence.

Theme:

Articles must relate to Consulting and Analytics and may cover topics such as:

  • Economics
  • Banking and Finance
  • Human Resource Management
  • Marketing and Branding
  • Operations and Manufacturing
  • Strategy / Consulting and Business
  • Technology in Business
  • New Business Opportunities & Entrepreneurship

Submission Guidelines:

  • Word Limit: 750–1250 words
  • Font: Times New Roman, Size: 12
  • Format: Word document (.doc/.docx)
  • File Naming: Author 1_Author 2_Institute Name.doc/.docx
  • Participants per Submission: 1–2 members

Author Details Required:

  • Full Name
  • Institute Name
  • Formal picture (white background)
  • Email ID
  • Contact number
  • Batch details

References:

  • All references must be cited properly.
  • Image sources must be clearly mentioned.

Deadline:

  • 25th December

column2: Digital Art Competition - Da Vinci Code
column45:
Event Format & Logistics:

  • The competition will be conducted entirely online.
  • Participants must use their own equipment (laptop, tablet, software, etc.).
  • Any 2D digital painting software is permitted.
  • All official communication will take place via Email and/or WhatsApp.

Creation Rules:

  • Only 2D digital paintings are allowed.
  • Artwork must be created from a blank canvas after the theme is announced.
  • Standard painting or textured brushes may be used.
  • Object-stamp brushes are strictly prohibited.
  • Use of pre-made assets, stock photos, or clip art is not allowed.
  • Reference images may be viewed externally, but must not be imported, traced, or directly copied.
  • All artwork must be fully original and entirely human-made.

AI Usage Policy:

  • AI tools may be used only for text-based brainstorming or idea generation.
  • AI-generated or AI-assisted images are strictly prohibited.
  • Any violation of this policy will result in immediate disqualification.

Mandatory Proof of Work:

  • Participants must provide proof of the creation process.
  • A 30–60 second time-lapse video showing the complete workflow is mandatory.
  • If your software does not support time-lapse export, submit a screen recording or a sequence of screenshots instead.
  • The original editable layered file must be submitted (e.g., .psd, .kra, .procreate).
  • All submitted files will be reviewed to verify originality.

Submission Guidelines:

  • Submissions must be made through the official submission link before the deadline.
    Late entries will not be accepted.
  • Participants must post their artwork on the specified platform using the provided tag and event hashtag.
  • Upload a ZIP file named: YourName_DigitalArt.zip, containing:
  • Final artwork
  • Time-lapse video
  • Editable layered source file

Code of Conduct:

  • All submissions must be original work.
  • Offensive, inappropriate, or plagiarized content will result in disqualification.
  • Participants must adhere to all rules, instructions, and deadlines.
  • Respectful behavior toward organizers and fellow participants is expected at all times.

column45:
About the event- Each team represents a galactic corporation competing to dominate a newly discovered star system called Epsilon Prime. Teams must use AI driven insights, business logic, negotiation, and strategy to expand, survive, and profit in a fast-changing cosmic economy. The game has three main rounds, each testing a different set of corporate and analytical skills.

Rules and guidelines – (Round Wise/ General):

Round 1:

  • Each team receives identical AI data packets.
  • Teams must evaluate planet habitability, resource potential, and risks.
  • All decisions must be backed by clear reasoning and data.
  • No cross-team trading or alliances are allowed in this round.
  • Teams submit a short justification of their chosen planets or investments.

Round 2:

  • Each team starts with their own planets, resources, and GC (Galactic Credits).
  • Teams can engage in trading, joint ventures, alliances, and planetary stake purchases.
  • Maximum of 2 resources can be traded per interaction.
  • All deals must be mutually agreed and recorded.
  • Organizers will announce AI Projects available for investment.

Round 3:

  • Teams receive a Galactic Buzz Alert (new challenge/disruption).
  • 10–15 minutes allowed to revise strategy.
  • Teams present a 3-minute pitch to judges.

Pitch must include:

  • How your strategy survives disruptions
  • Long-term profit model
  • Alliance logic or independence strategy
  • Risk mitigation
  • Role of AI in decisions

column2: Startup Hackathon 3.0 - Prizes worth 1,00,000 - Build your startup in 8 hours
column45:
Introduction:

  • Organized by The Mitraroop Foundation with strategic support from The Idea Company (TIC).
  • Aimed at building high-impact, debt-free ventures.
  • Designed for disruptors ready to solve real-world problems with scalable, zero-debt solutions.
  • 8-hour intensive hackathon focused on execution rather than ideation.

What Makes This Hackathon Different? (Algorithm of Success):

1. Major Startup Barriers Removed

  • Idea Barrier Eliminated: Participants get 25+ pre-validated, scalable business ideas.

  • Zero-Debt Launch Approach: Learn to build functional prototypes with zero initial investment, aligned with Mitraroop’s mission.

  • Execution-Driven Format: Skip brainstorming and jump directly into building.

2. Competition Structure (3 Phases in 8 Hours):

Phase 1: Idea Selection – 1 Hour

  • Choose one idea from a curated list of pre-vetted, high-impact business concepts.

Phase 2: Prototype Development – 5 Hours

  • Build a functional MVP (Minimum Viable Product).
  • Work in a disciplined, time-bound execution environment.

Phase 3: PMF Validation – 1.5 Hours

  • Test and refine your Product-Market Fit (PMF).
  • Present your Go-To-Market (GTM) plan.

Your Path to Becoming a Founder:

1. Mentorship Access

  • Direct guidance from industry experts.
  • Opportunity to interact with Anantrajsingh Baghel, CEO of The Idea Company (TIC).
  • Learn frameworks for algorithmic and discipline-based execution.

2. The Ultimate Validation

  • Successful teams earn Certificates supporting a debt-free, ethically grounded startup launch.
  • Recognition that can help accelerate your entrepreneurial journey.

column45:
Project Morpheus 2026: The Awakening, hosted by SIT Lonavala (STES), is here — a national-level awakening where code meets reality. Over 24 hours of intense building, brainstorming, and deployment, developers will break the simulation to solve real-world problems and showcase their innovation.

Key Details:

  • Registration & Round 1 (The Filter) Deadline: 28th January 2026

  • Final Onsite Round (The Construct): 26th – 28th February 2026

  • Venue: SIT Lonavala Campus & SKN Sinhgad Institute

  • Prize Pool: INR 2 Lakhs+

  • Theme: Real-World Impact Domains

Theme: Break the Simulation Participants must choose the "Red Pill" and solve critical challenges affecting millions. Instead of open innovation, teams must select one of five specific impact domains: EdTech, Healthcare, Women Safety, Agritech, or Fintech. The aim is to move beyond theory and build deployment-ready solutions.

Round 1 – The Filter (Idea Submission): Round 1 is currently live. As soon as you register, you can form your team and submit your vision via the presentation template. Both registration and submission close on 28th January 2026.

What to Submit:

  • Problem Statement: Select one of the defined problems (available at https://www.projectmorpheus.in/problem-statement).

  • Solution Approach: Describe your proposed architecture and the "Red Pill" solution.

  • Tech Stack: List the technologies (Web, AI/ML, Blockchain, IoT) you plan to use.

  • Impact: Highlight how your solution solves the specific "glitch" in the real world.

Evaluation Criteria for Round 1:

  • Innovation & Creativity (25%): How novel is the approach?

  • Problem Understanding: Does the team grasp the root cause?

  • Feasibility (15%): Can it be built within 24 hours?

  • Social Impact: Does it align with the mission to solve real problems?

Round 2 – The Code (Online Pitch): Those who passed The Filter now face the Council. This is a live Google Meet encounter where shortlisted teams pitch their solution in 10 minutes, followed by 3 minutes of rigorous questioning.

  • Dates: 1st – 7th February 2026

  • Format: Live Google Meet Pitch (Recorded)

  • What to Expect: Individual slots assigned by 31 January. The Council evaluates technical depth and clarity.

  • Outcome: Top 100 teams advance to The Construct.

Round 3 – The Construct (Final Onsite Round): Top shortlisted teams will be invited to SIT Lonavala for the grand 24-hour offline hackathon from 26th–28th February 2026. Teams will architect, code, and deploy their prototypes in a high-energy environment, presenting live to industry experts.

Engaging Activities:

  • Live mentorship from industry experts and founders

  • Networking with investors and accelerators

  • Incubation opportunities for top projects

  • Food, accommodation, and Matrix-themed swag

Conclusion: Project Morpheus 2026 serves as a launchpad for students to awaken to their potential. Don’t miss this opportunity to enter the construct and build the future!

Stay Connected

  • Website: www.projectmorpheus.in

  • Instagram: @projectmorpheus2026

  • Email: support@projectmorpheus.in

column45:
About the event:

  • Euphora is a fun and interactive event where participants take part in four different challenges—Cup Stack, Dare to Digest, Balance Battle, and The Mystery Box.
  • Each round brings a new activity that tests speed, creativity, balance, or guessing skills.
  • The event is designed to be enjoyable, engaging, and full of light-hearted competition for everyone.

Rules and guidelines:

  • General Rules
    • Enjoy the event and keep the energy positive.
    • Respect participants and coordinators.
    • Follow instructions for every round.
    • No pushing, physical interference, or arguments.
    • Cheating or damaging materials can lead to disqualification.
    • Be on time for your turn.
    • Maintain good sportsmanship.

Description of the round/rounds:

  • Round 1: Four players race to stack 10 cups while using a straw to distract others. Top three advance.
  • Round 2: The three do quick fun dares. Slowest tastes a quirky food combo. No elimination.
  • Round 3: Players hold a shown posture. First to lose balance is out. Two move to the final.
  • Round 4: Identify an object in a sealed box using touch only. Fastest correct guess wins the round.

column45:
Eligibility:

  • Open to all UG/PG students in engineering disciplines
  • Team size: 3–4 members
  • Inter-college teams: Allowed
  • Inter-specialization teams: Allowed
  • Internet access: Permitted

Judging Parameters:

  • Data Cleaning Accuracy
  • Analytical Creativity
  • Quality of Insights
  • Dashboard Visualization
  • Problem-Solving & Consistency

Rules:

  • Each participant can join only one team
  • Plagiarism or code/dashboard copying is prohibited
  • Only permitted tools/software may be used
  • All submissions must respect deadlines
  • Jury’s decision is final and binding
  • Offline presence at the venue is mandatory

Format:

  • 24-hour datathon with multiple missions
  • Each mission provides a dataset + real-world challenge
  • Tasks include Cleaning, Analysis, Visualization, and ML
  • No eliminations: all teams play till the end
  • Live leaderboard tracks team progress
  • Cash prize for overall winners (First 3 prizes) + special categories

column45:
Event Overview:

  • Decode the Corporation is a strategic business quiz designed for participants to think beyond the obvious.
  • Focuses on connecting the dots, uncovering hidden patterns, and recognizing strategic forces shaping top companies.
  • Covers iconic corporate moves, viral business moments, industry shakeups, consulting legends, and leadership decisions.
  • Encourages strategic thinking over mere memorization of frameworks or recent news.

Guidelines:

  • Total Questions: 30
  • Time Limit: 20 minutes
  • Marks per Question: 4
  • Negative Marking: -1
  • Eligibility: Open to all

Rules:

  • Each question has 4 options, only one correct answer.
  • Total quiz duration is 20 minutes.
  • Skipping questions is allowed, but revisiting answered questions is prohibited.
  • Switching tabs during the quiz is strictly prohibited.
  • Any malpractice or suspicious activity will result in disqualification.
  • No exceptions will be made for technical issues.
  • Tie-breaker: Participant who finishes earlier will be ranked higher.

column45:
About:

  • The Brew Cup Challenge 11.0 is a real-time business simulation game conducted over three rounds and nine days.
  • Focus areas include virtual production, supply chain management, and sales strategy.
  • Participants act as business tycoons, setting up production units while adapting to changing circumstances to maximize profits.
  • The challenge tests thoughtfulness, risk-taking ability, analytical skills, and foresight.
  • Each round increases in complexity to keep participants engaged.
  • Open to budding managers who can think on their feet and demonstrate business acumen.
  • A backstory will be shared soon to provide insights into the scenario “Knowledge is Power.”
  • Registration is required to participate.

Rules and Regulations:

  • Each team must consist of 2 members.
  • Open to undergraduate students, postgraduate students, and working professionals.
  • Teams can include members from different organizations and a mix of 1st-year and 2nd-year students.
  • No participant may join more than one team.
  • Teams must register with a unique team name and nominate a team leader.
  • Teams not adhering to the rules may be disqualified at any phase of the event.
  • Specific time windows will be provided for submitting inputs; late submissions will not be accepted.
  • Organizers reserve the right to modify rules.
  • Decisions made by the event organizers, sponsor, and knowledge partner are final and binding.

column45:
Event Overview:

  • A fast, real-world research face-off where participants analyze the “Stock of the Week” using the StockFox (formerly Investschool) app and credible external sources.
  • The participant with the sharpest, best-evidenced analysis wins.

What’s in it for you:

  • Competitive learning – apply a clear 5-step research flow on a real stock.
  • Big cash prizes every week – real rewards for number-backed insights.
  • Certificate of participation.
  • No entry fee – 100% free.

Prizes Worth 1,000 Every Week:

  • 1st Place: 500
  • 2nd Place: 300
  • 3rd Place: 200

Timeline (IST):

  • Research Form Submission Link Goes Live in WA Group: Friday, 6:00 PM.
  • Research Form Submissions Link Closes: Monday, 11:59 PM (end of day).
  • Results: Thursday – announced in Telegram Group.

How to Play & T&Cs:

  • Join the Telegram: Click here
  • Read the Guide on How to Play.
  • Join the TG community before Friday 6 PM (required; non-joiners not eligible for rewards).
  • Open the StockFox app and analyze the stock as shared in TG group using the guided flow. Credible external sources may be used with proper links in the form.
  • Submit analysis via the official Form (link shared in TG on Friday 6:00 PM IST). Deadline: Monday 11:59 PM IST.
  • One participant = one final submission. Resubmissions before the deadline will overwrite the previous entry.

Winner Selection & Tie-Breaker:

  • Judged on clarity, depth, evidence, originality, and practical takeaway.
  • Tie-breaker: earlier valid submission ranks higher.

Quick Rules:

  • Keep entries original; plagiarism or AI-generated content without sources leads to disqualification.
  • Cite credible sources (company filings, exchanges, reputed portals).
  • Organisers’ decision is final.
  • Multiple entries from the same participant will be disqualified.

column45:
Event Overview:

  • PeopleVerse: The HR Case Competition is the flagship national-level event organised by HRConnect, SIIB Pune.
  • Designed to bring together the brightest MBA minds from across India to compete, collaborate, and solve dynamic real-world HR challenges.
  • Blends analytical rigour with creative problem-solving through three immersive stages: rapid-fire screening, deep-dive case analysis, and boardroom-style grand showdown.
  • Mirrors the evolving HR landscape, encouraging participants to think like future HR leaders.
  • Each round tests HR capability, strategy, insight, execution, and leadership presence.


    We are proud to have Skilled Sapiens as our Knowledge Partner for this case competition. Skilled Sapiens is a leading educational and professional development platform founded in 2018, dedicated to empowering students, professionals, and young entrepreneurs through experiential learning and personalized mentorship. With expertise across domains such as Marketing, Finance, HR, Consulting, Product Management, and Entrepreneurship, Skilled Sapiens bridges the gap between campus and corporate through live sessions, industry insights, leadership programs, and hands-on project opportunities. Their strong mentor network and commitment to skill development have helped thousands of learners secure top placements and build impactful careers.

Eligibility:

  • Open to all MBA/PG students across India.
  • Team size: 1-2 members (inter-specialisation teams allowed).

Rules:

  • Each participant may be part of only one team.
  • Multiple teams from the same college are allowed.
  • Participants in the same team should be from the same college.
  • Participants must carefully read through and agree to the following terms and conditions before registering.
  • All decisions regarding eligibility, authenticity, and final judgments will rest with the organising committee of HRConnect, SIIB, Pune.

column45:
Trailblazer Treasure Quest:

  • Trailblazer Treasure Quest is ECell SIIB’s flagship entrepreneurial treasure hunt, crafted to blend startup thinking with highoctane campus adventure.
  • Participants first tackle an online startup quiz and problemsolving round, and the best teams earn a spot in an immersive onground treasure hunt during Ignisense 2026, where every clue is inspired by real founders, unicorns, and disruptive business models.

Why Participate?

  • Experience the journey of entrepreneurs through clues, cases, and campus-wide missions instead of typical lectures or case studies.
  • Round-1 qualifiers get discounted access to SIIB MUN at 1,699 (original fee: 1,999), giving them an edge in diplomacy and debating along with entrepreneurship.
  • Sharpen analytical ability, decision-making, teamwork, and time management by solving time-bound startup problems in a competitive environment.
  • Engage with SIIB’s E-Cell, peers from multiple colleges, and seniors during SIIB’s flagship fest Ignisense.

Guidelines:

  • Open to undergraduate and postgraduate students from any recognized institute.
  • Team size: 2–3 members per team.
  • All members must be from the same college.

Rules:

  • A student cannot be part of more than one team.
  • Round 1 will be conducted online; Round 2 will be conducted offline at SIIB, Pune.
  • Only shortlisted teams from Round 1 will be invited to the oncampus final round.
  • Teams must designate one team leader for all communication.
  • The organizing committee reserves the right to verify details and disqualify teams for any malpractice, misrepresentation, or violation of rules.
  • Decisions of the judges and organizing team will be final and binding.

column45:
1000 Faces: All That You Need to Know About Ignisense's Marketing Case Study Competition

In today’s dynamic world of marketing and branding, businesses must constantly innovate to stay ahead of the curve. "1000 Faces" challenges participants to delve deep into the marketing realm, tackle real-world business scenarios, and present groundbreaking strategies. Across three engaging rounds, participants will analyze, strategize, and demonstrate their prowess in creating impactful marketing campaigns. This is a remarkable opportunity to learn, compete, and connect with some of the sharpest minds across the nation.

Why Participate:

  • Real-World Problem Solving: Address actual marketing challenges and propose innovative, actionable solutions.
  • Skill Development: Sharpen analytical, creative, and presentation skills while deepening marketing domain expertise.
  • Networking: Collaborate with peers, connect with industry professionals, and showcase your potential.
  • Recognition: Stand out in the competition and elevate your professional profile.

Rules:

  • Open to postgraduate students.
  • Teams must have a maximum of 3 members.
  • Multiple teams from the same college are allowed.
  • All team members must be from the same college.
  • A student cannot participate in more than one team.
  • The organizing committee of Ignisense will make decisions on eligibility, authenticity, and final judgments, which will be binding.
  • The organizing committee of Ignisense reserves the right to modify the format and structure as and when necessary.

column45:
Ignisense-The Cultural Commitee of SIIB Pune, in collaboration with FinEquity-The Finance Club, presents “The Capitalist “ 2025-26.

The Capitalist is an exhilarating finance case competition that challenges participants to dissect a real-world business challenge and craft an ingenious financial strategy to tackle it. Teams will collaborate to perform financial analysis, crunch data, and construct a comprehensive financial plan tailored to meet the client's objectives. The pinnacle of the competition will be a dynamic PowerPoint presentation summarizing the team's findings, strategic recommendations, and implementation plan.

This is an invaluable opportunity for participants to showcase their financial acumen and gain hands-on experience formulating strategies for real-world clients. The winning team will be chosen based on the quality and practicality of their recommendations.

Rules:

  • The competition is open only to postgraduate students.
  • Each team must comprise 1-2 members.
  • Multiple teams from the same college are allowed.
  • Participants in the same team should be from the same college.
  • A student cannot be part of more than one team.
  • Participants must carefully read through and agree to the following terms and conditions before registering.
  • All decisions regarding eligibility, authenticity, and final judgments will rest with the organizing committee of The Capitalist, SIIB, Pune.

column45:
All that you need to know about Optiflow 2026 | Ignisense

In an ever-evolving world of Supply Chain Management (SCM), businesses must be agile and innovative to thrive. "Optiflow 2026" challenges participants to think critically, solve real-world problems, and demonstrate their expertise in SCM. Across three intense rounds, participants will strategize, analyze, and present compelling solutions to showcase their mastery of supply chain dynamics. This is a prime opportunity to learn, compete, and connect with the brightest minds across the country.

Why Participate:

  • Real-World Problem Solving: Address genuine supply chain challenges and propose actionable solutions.
  • Skill Development: Enhance analytical, presentation, and teamwork skills while deepening SCM domain knowledge.
  • Networking: Collaborate with top students, connect with industry experts, and highlight your potential.
  • Recognition: Boost your resume by standing out in the competition.

Rules:

  • Open to postgraduate students.
  • Teams must have a maximum of 3 members.
  • Multiple teams from the same college are allowed.
  • Members must be from the same college.
  • A student cannot participate in more than one team.
  • Each team must designate one leader to handle submissions and communication.
  • The organizing committee of Optiflow,SIIB will make decisions on eligibility, authenticity, and final judgments are binding.
  • The organizing committee of Optiflow,SIIB holds the right to modify the format and structure as and when necessary. 

Evaluation Criteria: 

  • Round 1: Accuracy and speed in the quiz.
  • Round 2: Depth of analysis, clarity of solutions, and relevance to modern SCM trends.
  • Round 3: Creativity, feasibility, and presentation of the solution.

column11: Suryodaya College of Engineering & Technology, Nagpur
column45:
Central India Hackathon - Chapter 3 (CIH 3.0) is a 24-hour national-level innovation marathon organized by Suryodaya College of Engineering & Technology (SCET), Nagpur, under the Youth Tech Connect (YTC) initiative. This edition brings a strong focus on the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (UN - SDGs), empowering young innovators to build scalable, sustainability-driven and impact-oriented solutions.

After the massive success of CIH 1.0 and CIH 2.0, this chapter returns bigger, sharper, and more challenge-driven, inviting developers, thinkers, and creators from across India to solve pressing global challenges aligned with SDG 3 and SDG 9.

Event Highlights

  • Date: 23 - 24 January 2026
  • Venue: Suryodaya College of Engineering & Technology (SCET), Nagpur, Maharashtra
  • Mode: Offline (Final Round at SCET Nagpur)
  • Duration: 24-Hour Hackathon
  • Registration Deadline: 23 December 2025
  • Team Size: 2 - 4 members
  • Process: Registration → Idea Submission → Shortlisting → 24-Hour Offline Finale
  • Certification: Certificates for all finalists
  • Perks: Goodies, swags, mentorship, networking, and incubation opportunities

Hackathon Theme Tracks (SDGs)

  • SDG 3: Good Health & Well-Being - Build solutions that enhance healthcare accessibility, diagnostics, mental health, emergency response, medical data analytics, assistive technologies, and wellness tools.
  • SDG 9: Industry, Innovation & Infrastructure - Create innovations around Industry 4.0, automation, smart manufacturing, sustainable infrastructure, digital solutions, supply chain tech, and socio-economic development.

Eligibility Criteria

  • Open to all students across India (UG, PG, diploma, etc.)
  • Team size of 2 - 4 members
  • Cross-college & interdisciplinary teams allowed
  • Passionate innovators, designers, and problem-solvers encouraged

Why Participate in CIH 3.0?

  • Work directly on global challenges aligned with UN SDGs
  • Get access to exclusive mentors, domain experts & startup founders
  • Hands-on exposure to Industry 4.0 tools and technologies
  • Chance to convert your innovation into a real-world startup
  • Build a strong project portfolio and gain national-level recognition
  • Experience an electrifying 24-hour offline hackathon environment

Hackathon Format

Round 1: Idea Submission

  • Participants must submit their innovative idea aligned with SDG 3 (Good Health & Well-Being) or SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation & Infrastructure). 
  • All submissions must be uploaded through Unstop in the form of a presentation.
  • A standard PPT template is provided in the brief/case and in the attachments section for uniform evaluation, and each team must compulsorily follow the given template.
  • Only original, non-plagiarized ideas will be accepted.

Round 2: Evaluation & Shortlisting

All submitted ideas will be reviewed by a panel of industry experts, academicians, and domain specialists.

Evaluations will be based on:

  • Innovation & creativity
  • Technical feasibility
  • SDG alignment
  • Potential real-world impact
  • Clarity & execution approach
  • The top 100 shortlisted teams will be selected for the 24-hour offline finale at SCET, Nagpur.

Round 3: Final Round Confirmation
Shortlisted teams must confirm their participation by paying a mandatory fee of 1000 per team within the given deadline.

This fee covers:

  • Accommodation for the event duration
  • Food arrangements for all team members
  • Upon successful payment, teams will receive an official confirmation and invitation to participate in the onsite 24-hour hackathon at Suryodaya College of Engineering & Technology, Nagpur.

Prize Pool Details

Each SDG track has been allocated a total prize pool of 50,000, and for both tracks (SDG 3 & SDG 9), the prize distribution is as follows:

1st Winner (Per Track)

  • 21,000 Cash Prize
  • 10,000 Worth Incubation Support

Runner-Up (Per Track)

  • 11,000 Cash Prize
  • 8,000 Worth Incubation Support

This ensures that both SDG tracks reward innovation, scalability, and real-world impact with strong financial and incubation support.

column45:
AIQrew 2025 is a fast-paced online quiz organised by CampusCrew for all tech-savvy minds who love artificial intelligence, problem-solving, and a bit of adrenaline under a ticking timer.

On 25th December 2025, you’ll get:

  • 25 handpicked questions on AI, tech, logic and aptitude
  • Just 15 minutes to prove you belong to the crew
  • A flexible attempt window from 7:00 PM to 9:15 PM – you can start anytime, as long as you begin on or before 9:00 PM

Once you hit Start, the clock doesn’t care. You’ll race through concepts, applications, scenarios and smart MCQs that test not just what you know, but how fast you think.

Whether you’re an AI beginner, ML enthusiast, or just someone who loves cracking smart quizzes, AIQrew 2025 is your chance to flex your brain, represent your campus, and earn serious bragging rights.

Format at a glance:

  • Date: 25th December 2025
  • Duration: 15 minutes (single attempt)
  • Questions: 25
  • Attempt window: 7:00 PM – 9:15 PM
  • Last start time: 9:00 PM sharp

Lock in your slot, join the crew, and let your AIQ do the talking.

column2: TalentX Youth Parliament: Inspiring Policies, Igniting Change
column45:
Talentx Youth Parliament 2025:

  • Taking forward the legacy of TalentX 2025, the latest edition of the event is organized by 'YOU CAN Foundation' in association with Career Honors.
  • An extraordinary platform for India's brightest minds to tackle real-world challenges, shape future policies, and emerge as the nation's next generation of changemakers.
  • Whether you're passionate about debate, policy innovation, or strategic governance, TalentX offers the arena to showcase your talents and make your voice heard.

Why Participate?:

  • An investment in your future: An accessible opportunity to engage with India's policy landscape whilst developing essential skills in critical thinking, communication, and leadership.
  • Participation Fee: 499/-
  • Date: 18th January 2026 at Jawahar Bhawan, Dr Rajendra Prasad Road, Opposite Shastri Bhawan, Windsor Place.

Rewards & Recognition:

  • Prize Pool: 10,000/- (Winner) and (Second Runner-up), plus certificates, mentorship opportunities through Career Honors, and exclusive access to partner policy think tanks.
  • Organizers:
    • Monis Shamsi is a passionate advocate for change, committed to empowering students and shaping the future of India through education and mentorship.
    • With over a decade of experience in the education sector, Monis seamlessly blends strategic planning, mentoring, and philanthropy to drive positive transformation.
    • He has been invited by more than 100 institutions across India as a Guest Speaker and TEDx Speaker.
    • Monis currently teaches Management students at IILM University in Design Thinking, Entrepreneurship, and Innovation.
    • As a certified Design Thinking Trainer trained by global experts, he brings an international perspective to education and leadership.
    • Through the You Can Foundation, Monis has organized 75 blood donation camps, saving over 15,000 lives, recognized by the Delhi Government’s SCBT, Central Government CSBT, national media, and government bodies.
    • He also leads Career Honors, a leading Career Advocacy Firm that collaborates with schools and universities to shape students’ career journeys.

Event Details: Choose from 2 Exciting Challenges (parliamentary Debate or Mock Cabinet Simulation):

  • The Policy Debate
    • Sharpen your oratory prowess and engage in rigorous intellectual discourse on policies shaping India's next two decades.
    • This Oxford-style debate competition challenges you to articulate compelling arguments, deliver rebuttals, and persuade audiences on critical policy questions.
    • Preliminary Rounds Format: Oxford Style 1v1 or 2v2
    • Debate policy-centric motions with emphasis on evidence, clarity, and strategic argumentation.
    • Face off against formidable opponents on thought-provoking motions.
    • Sample Motions:
      • "Should India adopt Universal Basic Income by 2035?"
      • "AI regulation is more urgent than climate regulation"
      • "NEP 2020 should mandate compulsory vocational training"
    • Final Round Challenge: A surprise motion revealed 30 minutes prior.
    • Recognition: Special Jury recognition, Runner-up Teams, Certificates, and exclusive goodies.
  • Mock Cabinet Simulation: Ministerial Deliberation
    • Step into the shoes of India's policymakers in this immersive simulation replicating the high-stakes environment of Cabinet governance.
    • Navigate complex crises, negotiate with fellow ministers, and draft unified national resolutions.
    • Role Allocation: Assume ministerial portfolios such as Education, Health, Finance, Environment, IT, Rural Development, and more.
    • Crisis Briefing (30 minutes): Example issues include Energy Crisis 2030, Managing Education During a Pandemic, or AI Misuse in Elections.
    • Cabinet Discussion (1 hour): Collaborate, negotiate, debate, and design resolutions balancing national priorities.
    • Press Conference (5 minutes per team): Defend your resolution under media-style questioning from the jury.
    • Demonstrate policy mastery and communication prowess.

Beyond Competition: Your Gateway to Impact, Recognition & Growth:

  • Universal Recognition: Certificates acknowledging civic leadership and policy excellence.
  • Special Jury Mentions: Awards for Most Impactful Contribution, Best Speaker, and Best Delegate.
  • Mentorship Opportunities: Direct access to policy mentors, think tanks, and experiential learning opportunities.
  • Internship Pathways: Direct connections to internship opportunities with leading policy organizations, think tanks, and research institutions.

Shape India's Tomorrow:

  • TalentX provides a platform to influence public discourse, challenge assumptions, and contribute meaningfully to India's growth story.
  • "Where today's students become tomorrow's policymakers. Where passion meets purpose. Where your ideas ignite change."
  • Step up, speak out, and make your mark on history.
  • Don’t miss this opportunity! Secure your spot at TalentX Youth Parliament 2025. Registration closes soon!

About the event- The Silicon C-Suite is an immersive, knowledge-driven quizzing event crafted to test participants’ awareness of Artificial Intelligence, emerging technology trends, innovation frameworks, and management insights. The event combines strategic thinking, quick reasoning, thus ensuring an engaging experience for the participants and tech enthusiasts.

Rules and guidelines – (Round Wise/ General) – General

  • Eligibility: Students from All disciplines across India
  • Registration: Unstop
  • Mode of Event: Hybrid mode. For participants coming online, meet link will be shared
  • All updates and announcements will shared through registered Email-IDs.

column2: Eco-Sansad : Youth Parliament for Sustainable India
column45:
Eco-Sansad: Youth Parliament for Sustainable India

Where Ideas Become Policies for Tomorrow

EcoSansad is an inter-college mock parliament event that empowers youth to ideate, draft, and debate sustainable policies for India’s future. The event simulates a real parliamentary setting where students act as political representatives, propose innovative bills, and strive to get their bills passed through democratic voting.

Event Objectives:

  • Promote awareness of legislative and policy-making processes.
  • Encourage critical thinking and structured policy debates.
  • Drive creative solutions for sustainability and growth.
  • Strengthen collaboration and leadership among youth.

Event Concept:

  • Participating colleges will represent fictional national parties and propose bills focused on sustainable development, innovation, or inclusive growth.
  • The event unfolds in two main phases: the Bill Submission phase and the Mock Parliament round, culminating in a public vote to decide the Best Bill of the Parliament.

Event Flow:

PHASE 1 (Registration Cum - Bill Submission) (5th December 2025 - 20th December 2025):

  • Each college submits a draft bill on sustainability or national growth.
  • Teams name their party after a fictional national political party.
  • Organizers shortlist 8–10 best bills based on creativity and feasibility.

PHASE 2 - Mock Parliament (22nd January 2025 – 2pm - 5pm):

  • Shortlisted teams are invited for the on-campus finale.
  • Each team presents (PPT) its bill in 10–15 minutes.
  • Other teams act as the opposition, questioning and debating the bill.
  • Judges vote for the best proposal.

Participation & Awards:

  • Eligibility: Open to undergraduate and postgraduate students (3–4 members per team).
  • Awards:
    • Winner – Rs. 5,000/-
    • Runner-Up – Rs. 3,000/-
    • 2nd Runner-Up – Rs. 2,000/-
  • e-Certificates for all participants.

Event Schedule & Logistics:

  • Bill Submission Opens – 5th December 2025
  • Deadline for Submission – 20th December 2025
  • Shortlisted Teams Announced – 5th January 2026
  • On-Campus Mock Parliament – 22nd January 2026
  • Venue: VESIM Campus 2, Auditorium
  • Time - 2pm - 5pm
  • Host Institute: Vivekanand Education Society’s Institute of Management Studies & Research

Expected Outcomes:

  • Encourages youth participation in policy-making.
  • Promotes sustainability-driven thinking.
  • Builds inter-college collaboration and civic engagement.
  • Generates implementable ideas for India’s future growth.

  • Participants must register on Unstop compulsorily.

  • The participants are expected to reach the venue 15 minutes prior.
  • Participants are required to carry their college IDs.
  • The decisions made by the organizing committee of IBS Hyderabad will be final and binding

column11: International Management Institute (IMI), Kolkata, 2/4 C, Judges Court Rd, Alipore, Kolkata, West Bengal 700027
column45:
InnovateX – Business Innovation Challenge

InnovateX is a real-world tech-enabled problem-solving competition where teams analyze a problem statement, design an innovative solution, and present a structured, impactful business/technology proposal.

Guidelines:

Eligibility:

  • Open to all engineering undergraduate and postgraduate students.
  • Students from any specialization of Engineering (B.E./B.Tech) can participate.
  • Inter-college teams are not allowed.
  • Inter-specialization teams are allowed.
  • Cross-year teams are permitted.

Team Formation

  • Team size: 2 to 4 members.
  • One person cannot be part of more than one team.
  • All members must belong to recognized educational institutions.

Competition Format

Round 1: Problem-Based Solution Pitch

  • A real-life managerial/technological problem will be provided.
  • Teams must propose a tech-enabled solution supported by logic, feasibility, and innovation.
  • Submit a presentation (PPT) as per the guidelines provided.
  • Top teams shortlisted based on creativity, clarity, and practicality will qualify for Round 2.

Round 2: Dataset-Based Analytics & Decision-Making Round

  • Shortlisted teams will receive a dataset.
  • Teams must analyze the data using relevant analytical tools.
  • Participants will answer the provided questions and build insights demonstrating data-driven decision-making.
  • The final submission must include:
    • Analysis summary
    • Visualizations (if required)
    • Structured responses to the questions

Duration

  • Round 1: Preparation window will be mentioned in the problem document.
  • Round 2: Duration mentioned along with the dataset (typically 1–2 hours).

Problem Statements / Questions

  • Round 1 will have one real-world problem statement provided to all teams.
  • Round 2 will include multiple data-based questions tied to the dataset.
  • The complexity will be moderate to advanced.

Rules

General Rules

  • All submissions must be original. Plagiarized or AI-generated work without modification will lead to disqualification.
  • Decisions made by the judging panel will be final and binding.
  • Teams must adhere to the deadlines for both rounds.
  • Any attempt to influence judges or organizers will result in disqualification.
  • Maintain professional conduct during presentations and Q&A rounds.

Round-Specific Rules

Round 1

  • Only one PPT submission per team.
  • Maximum slide limit will be communicated in the problem statement.
  • The proposed solution must be feasible, ethical, and implementable.

Round 2

  • External assistance or collaboration with non-team members is strictly prohibited.
  • Teams must use only the dataset provided.
  • The use of Python, Excel, Power BI, or other analysis tools is allowed unless specified otherwise.
  • Answers must be backed by logical reasoning and data insights.

Judging Criteria:

  • Creativity & originality of idea
  • Practicality and implementability
  • Clarity of thought and presentation
  • Depth of analysis (Round 2)
  • Data-driven justification
  • Overall coherence of the solution

About the Opportunity:

The Lola Coding Challenge, hosted by AKS University (AKSU), Satna, Madhya Pradesh, is a dynamic online event designed to ignite your passion for coding. This hackathon-style challenge invites teams to collaborate, innovate, and push the boundaries of their coding skills.

This online coding challenge is your chance to showcase your abilities, learn from peers, and immerse yourself in the world of coding. Whether you're a seasoned coder or just starting out, this opportunity offers a platform to create, solve, and excel in the realm of coding.

Eligibility and Registration:

  • Team Participation is required.

Ready to code? Join the Lola Coding Challenge and transform your ideas into reality!

column45:
Event Description:
 
Arbitrage Arena 2026 is a national-level quantitative finance competition where participants develop fully functional algorithmic trading models and portfolio optimization systems using real historical market data.
The competition tests participants on model design, risk management, and robustness under stress conditions such as flash crashes and volatility spikes.
 
Participants must choose one of two problem statements in the prelims and submit:
 
  • A Jupyter Notebook (.ipynb) containing the full model implementation
  • A Technical Report (.pptx) summarizing approach, logic, and performance
Top-performing teams qualify for the Final Hidden Challenge, where a new dataset and modeling problem are released. The finalists will have time until 31 January 2026 to submit their final notebook + report. Final results will be announced during Pravega 2026 (Feb 7–8).
 
What Participants Have to Do:
 
Step 1 — Choose ONE Problem Statement
Participants select either:
Problem 1: Surviving the Crypto Flash Crash:
Build a trading/risk model that survives flash crashes, minimizes drawdowns, and recovers quickly.
Problem 2: Cross-Asset Portfolio Optimization:
Construct a diversified systematic portfolio across equities, indices, and commodities with high Sharpe and low drawdowns.
 
Step 2 — Use ONLY the provided datasets
You will receive historical OHLCV data for:
  • Cryptocurrencies (BTC, ETH)
  • Equities (Tesla, Apple, Amazon, Microsoft, Nvidia, Meta)
  • NASDAQ Index
  • Commodities (Gold, Silver, Crude Oil)
  • Participants must load, clean, process, and analyze this data inside the notebook.
 
Step 3 — Build Your Model
 
Your model must include:
 
For Problem 1 (Crypto Flash Crash):
  • Volatility estimation
  • Crash detection logic
  • Position sizing / hedging strategy
  • Risk controls (stop-loss, exposure limits, drawdown limits)
  • Return analysis before, during, after crash
 
For Problem 2 (Cross-Asset Portfolio):
  • Return calculation
  • Risk estimation (covariance matrix, volatility, correlations)
  • Portfolio optimization logic (mean-variance, risk parity, regime switching, etc.)
  • Backtesting framework
  • Performance comparison across regimes
Step 4 — Submit Two Items
 
1. Jupyter Notebook (.ipynb)
Must contain complete code, explanation, outputs, and plots.
 
2. Technical Report (.pptx)
  • Max 12–15 slides summarizing:
  • Problem choice
  • Data processing
  • Model approach
  • Key formulas / logic
  • Backtest results
  • Metrics
REQUIRED NOTEBOOK FORMAT 
 
Your notebook must follow this structure:
 
1. Introduction
  • State the problem you selected
  • Outline your model idea
 
2. Data Import & Preprocessing
  • Load provided datasets
  • Handle missing values
  • Convert timestamps
  • Compute returns / log returns
  • Align multiple assets (if needed)
  • Include plots for:
  • OHLC
  • Return distributions
  • Volatility
 
3. Feature Engineering
Examples (participants choose relevant ones):
  • Moving averages, RSI, volatility
  • Correlation matrices
  • Crash indicators
  • Regime classification
 
4. Strategy / Model Design
Explain:
  • Algorithms used (with formula)
  • Risk management rules
  • Relevant constraints
 
5. Backtesting Framework
Must include:
  • Start & end dates
  • Position rules
  • Portfolio value calculation
  • Transaction cost assumption (default 0 unless implemented)
 
6. Evaluation Metrics (Mandatory)
 
For Problem 1 (Crypto Crash):
  • Crash Survivability Index (CSI)
  • Max Drawdown
  • Post-Crash Recovery Time
  • Sharpe Ratio
For Problem 2 (Portfolio):
  • Annualized Sharpe
  • Sortino
  • Max Drawdown
  • Volatility
  • Correlation Heatmap
  • Stress-test performance
 
7. Results & Plots
Must include:
  • Equity curve
  • Drawdown curve
  • KPI table
  • Rolling Sharpe
 
8. Conclusion
  • What worked
  • What failed
  • Possible improvements
 
EVALUATION & SCORING MATRIX:
 
Prelims Scoring (100 points total)
  • Component Weight
  • Model Logic & Innovation 25
  • Data Handling & Preprocessing 10
  • Risk Management 15
  • Backtesting Framework 20
  • Evaluation Metrics Quality 20
  • Clarity of Explanation (Notebook + PPT) 10
 
Top teams qualify for finals based purely on these scores.
 
Final Round Scoring (100 points total)
Based on the hidden problem:
  • Component Weight
  • Model robustness 30
  • Performance under stress scenarios 30
  • Risk-adjusted returns 20
  • Reliability & reproducibility 20
only your final submissions are judged.
 
IMPORTANT DATES:
  • Registration 5–21 Dec 2025
  • Prelims Submission 5–25 Dec 2025
  • Prelims Result Announced Early Jan 2026
  • Hidden Final Problem Released Early Jan 2026
  • Final Submission Deadline 31 Jan 2026
  • Winner Announcement 7–8 Feb 2026 (Pravega)
 
Rules:
  • Use only provided datasets
  • Submissions must be original
  • Notebook must run end-to-end
  • Late submissions are not evaluated
  • Judges’ decision is final

column45:
About:

  • A product manager ensures user needs are met and delivers key outcomes on time.
  • They guide a product through its entire lifecycle from ideation to launch.
  • They focus on strategy, execution, and continuous improvement.
  • If you have strong vision and passion for products, PMx 2026 is the right place to begin.

About Product Management Expedition (PMx):

  • PMx is a flagship product case study competition hosted by UDGAM, the official E-Summit of IIT Guwahati.
  • It is part of UDGAM 2026, organised by E-Cell IIT Guwahati.
  • The competition invites young visionaries, analytical thinkers, and problem-solvers to showcase strategic insight and real-world problem-solving skills.
  • It is an opportunity for aspiring product managers and entrepreneurs to explore product thinking and kickstart their journey.

Rewards:

  • Prizes worth INR 2,50,000
  • Internship opportunities, industrial mentorship
  • Premium courses and mock interviews
  • Certificate of appreciation for the top 15 winning teams
  • Participation certificates for all valid submissions

Points to Note:

  • Team size: Minimum 2 and maximum 4
  • Team members can be from different colleges
  • Open to all product enthusiasts, irrespective of branch or field
  • Ideal for individuals with curiosity and strong problem-solving desire

column2: Vanguard 2026: The Flagship Strategy Case Competition
column45:
BL Conclave is the PGP-BL flagship event at IIM Kozhikode for everything “business and leadership” – industry conversations, strategic problem-solving, and high-energy campus competitions. BL Conclave is curated by PGP-BL, IIM Kozhikode’s one year MBA programme.

About the Event:

  • Vanguard 2026 is the flagship strategy case competition hosted by PGP-BL at IIM Kozhikode.
  • It is a national, multi-round competition designed to test problem-solving, strategy formulation, business acumen, and storytelling.
  • Open to all students across India from UG and PG.
  • Participants step into the shoes of management consultants to architect the revival of Fabbrix, a mid-market fashion brand facing major challenges.
  • Participants analyze consumer sentiment shifts, operational breakdowns, and create a boardroom-ready turnaround plan.
  • Cross college teams are allowed to participate 

Round 1: The Vanguard Quiz (Qualifier):

  • A fast-paced strategy and business quiz.
  • Top 75 teams advance to Round 2.

Format:

  • Online, timed
  • Multiple-choice questions
  • Topics include strategy, consulting fundamentals, markets, business logic, and case-style thinking

Round 2: The Fabbrix Case Submission:

  • Shortlisted teams receive the first Fabbrix case document.

Deliverables:

  • 2 content slides plus 1 appendix slide in PDF format
  • Strategic recommendation and rationale
  • Data-backed insights and feasibility
  • Clear articulation of trade-offs
  • Top 10 teams advance to the Grand Finale

Round 3: The Vanguard Grand Finale:

  • Top 10 teams present their strategy to the jury.

Final Round Deliverables:

  • 6 content slides plus 2 appendix slides in PDF or PPT format
  • Presentation time slots shared later
  • Q&A round included
  • Depth, creativity, and storytelling will be evaluated

Awards:

  • Winner: 30,000
  • Runner-up: 20,000
  • Second Runner-up: 10,000

column11: Vidyanagar, Vidya Vihar East, Vidyavihar, Mumbai, Maharashtra 400077
column45:
About Agri-Tech Hackathon 2026:

Agri-Tech Hackathon 2026 is a national-level offline hackathon that brings together the brightest minds to innovate, collaborate, and develop technology-driven solutions for agriculture. Hosted by K. J. Somaiya School of Engineering (KJSSE), this event will be a 24-hour coding sprint where participants will work on challenges spanning precision agriculture, supply chain optimization, farmers’ empowerment, biofuel innovation, and open innovation in agriculture.

This is your chance to code, create, and revolutionize the agri-tech landscape with cutting-edge technologies like AI, IoT, blockchain, and data analytics. The hackathon will conclude with a pitching round where teams present their solutions to an esteemed panel of judges from industry and academia.

Eligibility & Team Formation:

  • Teams must consist of 3 to 5 members.
  • Participants must be undergraduate students from any discipline.
  • Teams can have members from different colleges.

Event Structure:

Round 1: Abstract Submission (Online)

  • Teams must submit a detailed abstract of their idea along with an Abstract (PDF) by January 05, 2026.
  • Submissions must follow the provided template.
  • Selected teams will be invited for the on-site hackathon at KJSSE, Mumbai.

Round 2: On-Site Hackathon (Offline at KJSSE, Mumbai)

  • Shortlisted teams must report to the venue on February 05, 2026.
  • Teams must build their project within the 24-hour hackathon duration (February 05-06, 2026).
  • Pre-existing projects are not allowed.
  • Food and snacks during the hackathon will be provided by the organizers.
  • A nominal fee of 200 per team is required after selection for Round 2.
  • Please note that the fee is applicable for the team who are shortlisted for Round 2.

Hackathon Tracks:

  • Theme 1: Next-Gen Agri-Tech

Tagline: Reinventing farming through intelligence and automation.
Focus: IoT, AI, Computer Vision, Autonomous Robotics, Drones, Predictive Analytics
What participants can expect:
Problem statements centered around next-generation farming technologies —
including multi-sensor crop monitors, autonomous rovers, solar-powered
drones, precision spraying systems, smart seed-sowing drones, AI disease
identification, and farm digital twins.

  • Theme 2: Agri-Market Access

Tagline: Connecting farms to markets with trust, transparency, and technology.
Focus: Post-harvest innovation, Smart storage, Quality grading, Blockchain, Demand
forecasting, Direct marketplaces
What participants can expect:
Challenges designed to improve the entire supply chain — such as smart cold
storage with spoilage sensors, automated grading machines, freshnesstracking packaging, blockchain-based traceability, AI-driven demand
prediction, and direct farmer-to-consumer platforms.

  • Theme 3: Farmer Empowerment

Tagline: Technology that puts knowledge and capability directly in the hands of
farmers.
Focus: Affordable tools, Offline solutions, Hyperlocal insights, Multilingual AI,
AR/VR training, Community platforms
What participants can expect:
Solutions that uplift farmers directly — including low-cost crop diagnostic
devices, compact weather stations, solar-powered information kiosks,
regional-language advisory chatbots, AR/VR learning modules, and
collaborative knowledge-sharing apps.

  • Theme 4: Green Growth

Tagline: Driving sustainable agriculture for a climate-resilient future.
Focus: Soil regeneration, Water conservation, Carbon monitoring, Climate
intelligence, Sustainable farming
What participants can expect:
Innovations targeting sustainability — such as IoT irrigation controllers, soil
health scanners, carbon capture monitoring devices, soil regeneration
dashboards, carbon-credit trading platforms, and AI water-usage prediction
systems. 

 

  • Theme 5: Open Innovation

Tagline: Innovate beyond boundaries — your problem, your solution.

Focus: Participant-driven ideas aligned with agriculture, sustainability, and emerging technologies
(AI, IoT, Robotics, Data Science, Blockchain, Climate-Tech, Rural Empowerment, Agri-FinTech, etc.)

What participants can expect:
This theme gives participants complete creative freedom to propose their own problem statements, as long as they align with the broader objectives of Agri-Tech Hackathon 2026. Teams can identify real-world agricultural challenges from their local communities, personal observations, or research insights.

Participants may submit innovations involving —

  • novel agri-tech hardware or software tools,

  • unique farmer-centric applications,

  • technology for rural value chains,

  • sustainable and climate-resilient ideas,

  • market linkage or financial inclusion concepts,

  • or any solution that advances modern agriculture.

Teams may also choose from the pre-existing problem statements provided on the official website if they prefer structured challenges.

 

Additional Information:

  • The decision of the organizing team will be final.
  • Teams cannot be changed or shuffled after registration.
  • AI/ML and emerging technologies are welcomed for implementation.
  • The event will conclude with a networking attended by judges, sponsors, and speakers.

column45:
Prometeo 2026 marks the latest edition of IIT Jodhpur’s National Technical and Entrepreneurial Festival. Inspired by Prometheus, the Greek fore-thinker who gifted humanity the fire of knowledge, Prometeo embodies the spirit of innovation, creativity, and technological progress.

The fest features an exciting mix of talks, workshops, and competitions that immerse participants in emerging technologies. In an era defined by global challenges, Prometeo fosters collaboration and builds a community of problem-solvers striving to elevate, transform, and conquer.

About Quantalytics:

Quantalytics is a quantitative research and algorithmic trading event crafted for budding quants and finance enthusiasts. The objective is simple yet challenging:
Develop, backtest, and evaluate a quantitative trading strategy using the provided Problem Statement.

Participants must:

  • Develop or explore quantitative/statistical tools
  • Automatically detect trading signals
  • Formulate a clear hypothesis
  • Backtest the strategy using any platform of their choice (e.g., Blueshift, Algobulls, QuantConnect)
  • Evaluate the profitability and robustness of the approach

For updates, clarifications, and discussions, join our official Discord community and connect with fellow participants.

Guidelines:

  • Team Size: 1–3 members
  • Inter-College Teams: Allowed
  • Students from any recognised engineering college/institute are eligible
  • Teams may include members from different colleges or specialisations
  • The event is conducted offline as part of Prometeo 2026
  • Every team must have an appropriate team name (cannot be changed later)
  • Each team must nominate a Team Representative/Leader during registration
  • The representative must provide valid contact details (email ID, mobile number) for communication

Rules:

  • Any discrepancy or violation may lead to penalties or disqualification
  • All submissions must be made before the deadline; late entries will be penalised
  • The decision of the judges is final and binding

Note: Please refer to the official rulebook for submission formats, required files, and detailed evaluation criteria.

column45:
About the event:

  • The Singularity Trials is a fast-paced adventure set in the Hub, a digital universe that has suddenly broken down.
  • A major system error has caused several Data Centres to stop working, and the entire system is on the verge of shutting down.

Rules and regulations:

  • All participants must always follow the host’s instructions.
  • Use only materials provided by the organizing team; no external items are permitted.
  • No rough play, pushing, or interference with other teams' materials.
  • Complete challenges within the designated time limit.
  • Respect fellow participants and maintain professionalism.
  • Always avoid disruptive behaviour.
  • Teams must return to Galaxy Hub after each Data Centre activity to receive the next Cosmic Coordinate.
  • Teamwork and collaboration are essential for success.
  • Entry and exit times will be logged and tracked for scoring.

column45:
Demand Supply AI is a simulation game where participants act as policymakers and find solutions to different market-failure situations. Teams can use AI for assistance with the latest market updates or to find optimal solutions to the given problem.

Rules and Guidelines:

  • Round 1 – Demand – Supply – AI:
    • Maintain decorum; no talking during case presentation.
    • No disrespect towards the organizing team.
    • Use of AI will be strictly time-based and monitored by the operations team.
  • Round 2 – Government Conquer:
    • Judge’s decision will be final.
    • No disrespect towards the organizing team and judging panel.
    • Use of AI will be strictly time-based and monitored by the operations team.

column45:
About the Event:

  • A mind-bending simulation where teams resurrect EVE, the last AI capable of learning from humans, after a solar flare wipes out digital decision-making.
  • Participants rediscover analytics, rebuild reasoning, and redefine leadership in a world where humans must learn to think again.

Rules and Regulations:

  • Use only event-provided data and props.

column45:
About the Event:

  • The Neuralverse – Reboot Reality, an immersive sci-fi themed event where participants are pulled into a fractured digital world after Project NOVA, a powerful AI experiment, malfunctions and shatters reality. Trapped inside the Neuralverse, a realm controlled by AI, they must navigate four neural layers that test logic, creativity, decision-making, and emotional intelligence. Only by successfully overcoming these cognitive challenges can participants restore balance and escape the AI-ruled dimension, embodying the theme: When creation becomes the creator.

Rules and Guidelines:

  • Eligibility: All streams.
  • Team size: 2-3 members
  • Mode: Hybrid
  • Each game will have a set time limit for answering, and points will be rewarded.

Round-wise Guidelines:

Round 1:

  • Follow the exact sequence format provided.
  • No external tools or hints allowed.
  • Submit within the given time limit, late submissions won’t be counted.

Round 2:

  • Distinguish between real and AI-generated images.
  • No points for this round 

Round 3:

  • Make decisions only from the options given.
  • Each choice affects Efficiency & Humanity, balance both.
  • No revisiting previous decisions once submitted.
  • Teams must justify choices briefly when prompted.

Round 4:

  • A light non-scoring activity where teams classify humorous prompts to build engagement.

Round 5:

  • Identify the shortest valid route using the provided network map.
  • Only one final route submission per team.
  • Accuracy > speed, but fastest correct answer gets bonus advantage.
  • No external pattern-solving tools or devices allowed.

Round 6:

  • Read the case carefully and stick to the given information — no assumptions outside the scope.
  • Identify the core dilemma and stakeholders, then evaluate 2–3 possible actions with pros, cons, and risks.
  • Follow the time structure strictly: use your analysis window wisely and finish slides before the prep time ends.
  • Present a clear, feasible, and ethically sound recommendation supported by logical reasoning.
  • Follow all event rules stay within time limits, use only permitted resources, and ensure originality of ideas.

column45:
About the Event:

  • Brand Parliament is a high-intensity corporate simulation where participants assume roles as brand leaders and policymakers responding to AI-driven crises.This edition emphasizes ethical dilemmas, technological risks, data breaches, automation failures, misinformation, and brand reputation challenges in the age of artificial intelligence. The event captures authentic boardroom pressure, demanding quick thinking, strategic communication, intense negotiation, lobbying, and policy reasoning. Participants represent major brands, respond to unfolding crises in real time, debate proposed regulations, form alliances, and vote on decisions that determine industry outcomes.

Rules and Guidelines:

  • Participants must stick to allotted brand traits
  • Maintain professional decorum throughout the event
  • Adhere strictly to time allocations
  • Short notes are permitted during preparation phases only; presentations and discussions must be delivered without reading prepared scripts

column45:
About the event:

  • Multi-day competition designed to merge public speaking, logic, and creativity while exploring the intersection of AI and humanity in the professional world.
  • Participants use their assigned professions and unique traits to navigate complex ethical and technical dilemmas, culminating in a debate where they must switch stances under pressure (The Pivot) and a tribunal where they must defend a strategic blueprint for AI's future viability in their field.
  • The overall goal is to push speakers to balance emotion, ethics, and intellect, showcasing advanced soft skills and debating agility.

Rules and Guidelines:

  • Goal: Merge public speaking, logic, and creativity while balancing emotion, ethics, and intellect.
  • Role: Maintain your assigned Profession and Oxymoronic Trait (Day 1).
  • Preparedness: Cannot rely on a prepared speech; spontaneous defense is crucial.
  • Focus: All segments must address the core theme of AI vs. Human decision-making.

Roundwise Rules:

  • Round 1
    • Setup: Theme, AI Situation, Profession, and Oxymoronic Trait are revealed.
    • Stance: Participant 1 argues Initial Stance (e.g., Human/Empathy); Participant 2 argues Opposite Stance (AI/Logic).
    • The Pivot: Host interrupts; Participant 1 must immediately switch to the Opposite Stance (1.5 mins).
    • Cohesion: Participants must logically bridge the two opposing arguments while maintaining their character/trait.
    • Assessment: Judges heavily score creativity and logical cohesion during the Role Reversal.
  • Round 2
    • Role: Represent a profession (e.g., Doctor) and come up with a motion.
    • Motion: Present a motion (1 min) regarding AI's impact on your field.
    • Tribunal: Defend your motion against three angles: Legal, Public, and Industry.
    • Crossfire: Engage in cross-discussion with other professions (3 mins).
    • Decision: The motion is announced as "Passed" or "Denied" in the AIverse.
  • Round 3
    • Eligibility: Only "Passed" motions from Day 2 proceed.
    • Task: Prepare a Strategy Blueprint (paper) and a 3-minute presentation.
    • Pillars: Blueprint must address Ethical/Legal, Public Adoption/Training, and Technical Roadmap/Phasing.
    • Scrutiny: Defend the feasibility and resource demands of your strategy against Tribunal challenges (2 mins).

column45:
The event is open to all management verticals from B-Schools and professionals across India, including:

  • General Management
  • Marketing
  • Finance
  • Operations
  • Information Technology
  • Human Resources

Note: The article should be original and related to Analytics & IT.

Key Details:

  • We are seeking original insights backed by references.
  • The best articles will be featured in our magazine and awarded a cash prize.
  • Results will be announced within 10-15 days post-28th December 2025.

Guidelines:

  • This is an individual event.
  • If there are issues regarding the submission link, please email your article to analyticsclub@iimrohtak.ac.in.
  • Mention your Name and Institute/Organization in the article.
  • Use the following file naming format: Individual's name_Organization name_Name of the article.

Format:

  • Font: Times New Roman
  • Size: 12
  • Word Limit: 1000-1500 words
  • File Type: .doc/.docx
  • Deadline for Submission: 28th December 2025

Rules:

  • Plagiarism will not be accepted.
  • Articles must be exclusively written for IIM Rohtak, with references mentioned.
  • All graphics, including images, graphs, and illustrations, should be of high quality.

Awards:

  • The winning entries will receive a total cash prize of Rs. 500 and e-certificates.
  • There is no participation certificate.

column45:
IndiaPreneur 15.0 – Dare to Dream (Overview):

  • Flagship national entrepreneurship competition by IGI Group & Indira University
  • Encourages bold, innovative, high-impact business ideas
  • Participants develop, refine, and pitch their startup concepts to industry experts
  • Supported by Swakiyam Centre for Incubation & Innovation
  • Platform to showcase entrepreneurial vision and create real-world impact

Eligibility:

  • Open to all undergraduate and postgraduate students

Rewards:

  • Winner: 100,000
  • 1st Runner-Up: 60,000
  • 2nd Runner-Up: 40,000

Perks:

  • Professional mentoring from industry experts and entrepreneurs
  • Feedback from investors and seasoned founders
  • Skill development through workshops and sessions
  • Access to potential investors for idea funding

Registration:

  • Open from November 27, 2025, to December 31, 2025
  • Submission required: Problem statement + Business Model Canvas (PDF)

Judging Criteria:

  • Desirability – solves a real problem
  • Feasibility – can be developed/produced
  • Viability – financially sustainable
  • Market potential – large and growing market
  • Competitive advantage – unique strength
  • Innovation – differentiated and creative solution

Timeline:

  • Elimination Round: Shortlisting based on problem statement & BMC (Results by Jan 31, 2026)
  • Online Round (Feb 17, 2026): Presentation to judges
  • Semi-Finale Online (Feb 26–27, 2026): Top 25 teams present
  • Grand Finale On Campus (March 28, 2026): Top 6 teams pitch to VCs, angels, and Fortune 500 executives; includes Startup Expo and Entrepreneurship Summit
  • Outstation finalists receive 3rd AC train fare, hotel stay, and meals

About Indira University:

  • Established under the Indira Group of Institutes founded in 1994
  • Offers programs from kindergarten to PhD
  • Focus on value-based learning, innovation, and industry collaboration
  • Recently transformed into Indira University (Pune)
  • Aims to nurture leadership, employability, and lifelong learning
  • Committed to contributing to India’s economic and societal progress

About Swakiyam Centre for Incubation & Innovation (IU):

  • Institutional initiative to promote entrepreneurship development
  • Supports student and community innovators through incubation and mentoring
  • Encourages holistic growth and entrepreneurial mindset
  • Philosophy: “Entrepreneurs take the route less traversed.”

Objectives:

  • Become a benchmark destination for incubation and mentoring
  • Achieve self-sustainability within 5 years through partnerships and programs
  • Provide end-to-end startup incubation services using innovative methods

Proposed Scope – Areas of Development:

  • Startup incubation with comprehensive support
  • Mentoring for entrepreneurs
  • Industry exposure via experts and internships
  • Platforms for events and entrepreneurial engagement

Areas of Focus:

  • Sector-agnostic incubation
  • Multidisciplinary collaboration
  • Facilitation from ideation to commercialization

column45:
DRISHTI-NE Hackathon Overview: Leading the North East Digital Transformation

DRISHTI-NE Hackathon is the premier AI innovation challenge exclusively for the North Eastern Region, launched at the Regional AI Impact Conference in Shillong by the Hon’ble Chief Minister of Meghalaya. Designed as a strategic initiative under the IndiaAI Mission, the hackathon aims to position Meghalaya and the NER as national leaders in applied AI innovation.

Organised by IIM Shillong (Knowledge Partner) in collaboration with the Government of Meghalaya and MATH T-Hub, this hackathon seeks bold, practical and high-impact AI solutions that address real challenges unique to the North East, ranging from climate resilience and disaster management to language inclusion, rural healthcare, education, public service delivery, and more.

The program has been structured to mimic a full innovation lifecycle:
Ideate → Build → Validate → Pitch → Deploy.

Participants will go beyond theoretical proposals and develop functional AI prototypes aligned with the NER’s needs and the IndiaAI Mission’s 7 strategic focus areas.

What We Expect From Participants:

Participants are expected to:

  • Identify a genuine North-Eastern problem that AI can solve meaningfully.

  • Demonstrate why AI is necessary for the proposed solution.

  • Use responsible AI principles, including DPDP compliance, bias mitigation, and transparency.

  • Build a functional prototype/MVP, not just mockups.

  • Provide clear technical documentation, datasets, and architectural design.

  • Show feasibility: Could this solution realistically be piloted by a state department or community?

  • Showcase the potential social impact, inclusiveness, and scalability.

Hackathon Themes:

Participants must align their ideas with one or more of the following:

  • AI for Governance & Public Good

  • AI for Healthcare & Wellness

  • AI for Agriculture & Climate Resilience

  • AI for Education & FutureSkills

  • AI for Accessibility & Inclusion

  • Ethical & Responsible AI

  • Indigenous Generative AI

  • Open Innovation (Wildcard)

Eligibility:

Participants must be connected to any of the 8 NE states (Meghalaya, Assam, Arunachal Pradesh, Manipur, Mizoram, Nagaland, Tripura, Sikkim) through one of the following tracks:

Track A - Students

  • UG, PG, Diploma, and PhD students studying in any NER institution.

  • Students originally from NER but studying anywhere in India.

Track B - Professionals / Startups

  • Working professionals, freelancers, startups based in the NER.

  • Individuals originally from NER but working elsewhere in India.

Team Size:

  • 2 to 5 members per team. Interdisciplinary teams & Gender-diverse teams are encouraged.

column45:
Starting the challenge with a clever riddle round featuring puzzles rooted in Banking, Accounting, Finance, and Taxation, and for those who advance, step into the role of an AI-powered loan officer where you decide which loans to approve or reject based on key financial factors — with your AI lifeline guiding you through the toughest calls.

Round 1:

  • Riddle-based questions combining BAFT and Ai
  • Pen and paper will be provided to all the participants.
  • There will be 25 riddles in total.
  • You’ll get 1 minute and 30 seconds per riddle to answer.
  • Answers must be written clearly on the sheet provided.
  • Once time’s up, you cannot go back to previous questions.
  • Use of mobile phones or smart devices is strictly prohibited.

Round 2: Smart Sanction:

  • Team Size: 2 members per team.
  • Time Limit: 40 minutes total.
  • Task: Act as Loan Officers and decide to Approve or Reject loan applications.
  • Tools Allowed:
    • Excel + GPT (for scoring and calculations under the surveillance of our volunteers)
  • Disqualification Criteria:
    • Plagiarism, copying from other teams, or irrelevant AI responses will lead to immediate disqualification.
    • Late submissions beyond the time limit will not be accepted.

A thrilling mix of quick challenges, mystery tasks, brainy guesses, and high-energy dares designed to test your teamwork, speed, and spontaneity — all packed into one fun-filled experience.

Rules and Regulations:

  • Team Composition: Each team must consist of two members.
  • Time Limit: The entire event must be completed within 2.5 hours.
  • There is no specific time limit per game, but the overall time constraint applies.
  • No Communication: Team members are not allowed to communicate with each other during individual tasks.
