column11: The LNM Institute of Information Technology
column45:
Brandwagon is the flagship business quiz organized by Quizzinga, the LNMIIT Quiz Club, and held annually during Plinth, LNMIIT’s renowned Techfest. Known for testing participants' knowledge of business, brands, and global markets, Brandwagon brings together the brightest minds to compete in a challenging and exciting two-round competition. With a focus on critical thinking, awareness of industry trends, and quick recall, Brandwagon is the perfect platform for business enthusiasts to showcase their skills.

Guidelines:

  • Format: On-site Business Quiz with two competitive rounds.
  • Round 1: Written preliminary round to assess general business knowledge, brand recall, and understanding of economic trends.
  • Round 2: The top six teams from Round 1 qualify for the finals, where they face off in an intense, quiz-show style format.

Format:

  • Type: On-site Business Quiz
  • Objective: Test participants' knowledge and acumen in the areas of business, branding, corporate affairs, and market dynamics.

Rules:

  • Eligibility: Open to teams passionate about business and current events.
  • Team Size: Teams of 3 members.
  • Round 1 - Written Preliminary Round:
    • Teams answer a series of questions covering various aspects of business and economics.
    • The six highest-scoring teams will advance to the final round.
  • Round 2 - Quiz Finals:
    • Format: Classic quiz format with a mix of buzzer rounds, visual questions, and situational analysis.
    • Points awarded for correct answers; penalties for incorrect responses in select rounds.
    • The team with the highest score at the end of the finals is declared the winner.
    • Conduct: All participants are expected to adhere to the quizmaster's rulings. Misconduct or use of unfair means will lead to disqualification.

Judging Criteria:

Teams will be judged on:

  • Round 1: Performance in the preliminary written round.
  • Final Round: Total score achieved in the quiz finals.

Round Details:

Round 1: Written Preliminary Round:

  • Date: [ Plinth Day 1 ]
  • Gameplay: A written round that tests teams on their knowledge of business, branding, corporate news, and economic concepts. The top six teams based on scores will qualify for the final round.

Round 2: Quiz Finals:

  • Date: [ Plinth Day 2 ]
  • Gameplay: A live, interactive quiz round with different question formats, including rapid-fire, buzzer rounds, and visual clues. The final round determines the top team based on cumulative scores.

Team Size:

  • 3 members per team

column45:
Concept Note (Points Format):

Event Overview:

  • Event Name: Business Revival Blueprint – Strategic Turnaround Competition
  • Team Size: Exactly 2 members
  • Event Type: Online competition (Unstop)
  • Theme: Business Revival & Turnaround Strategy

Event Description

  • Participants act as turnaround consultants for distressed or failed businesses.
  • Each team is assigned a real-world failed business case.
  • Teams must:
  • Analyse the root causes of failure
  • Develop a structured revival plan
  • Present their solution through an 8–12 slide PPT
  • Key skills involved:
  • Analytical thinking
  • Creativity
  • Strategic problem-solving
  • Business modelling
  • Market & financial analysis

Turnaround Strategy Must Cover:

  • Business background and cause-of-failure analysis
  • SWOT analysis and market assessment
  • Proposed revival model
  • Strategic interventions
  • Marketing and branding roadmap
  • Operational restructuring and cost optimization
  • Financial projections and viability
  • Risk mitigation plan

Round Structure:

Round 1 – Final Round: Business Revival Presentation (Online)

  • Teams must directly submit a PPT/PDF with the complete revival strategy.
  • Presentation length: 8–12 slides

Submission Format:

  • Accepted formats: PPT / PPTX / PDF
  • First slide must include:
  • Team name
  • Business name

Rules & Regulations:

Team Structure:

  • Team size must be exactly 2 members.
  • Participants must belong to a recognized educational institution.
  • One member should be designated as the team leader for communication.

General Rules:

  • Presentation length: 8–12 slides.
  • Content must be original, logical, and data-driven.
  • Plagiarism or use of copyrighted content is prohibited.
  • No political, obscene, or offensive content allowed.
  • Only one submission per team is permitted.
  • Jury decisions are final and binding.

Technical Requirements:

  • File format: PPT / PPTX / PDF

Evaluation Criteria (Table Converted into Points):

Evaluation Rubrics & Weightage:

  • Problem Diagnosis & Root Cause Analysis – 25%
  • Creativity & Feasibility of Revival Plan – 25%
  • Strategic & Financial Soundness – 20%
  • Market Understanding & Competitive Insight – 15%
  • Presentation & Communication Clarity – 15%

Awards & Recognitions:

Winner Team:

  • Cash prize / Gift hampers (as per OJAS 2025)

  • Winner certificates

  • Spotlight feature on OJAS social media

Runner-Up Team:

  • Cash prize / Hampers

  • Runner-Up certificates

  • Social media feature

For All Participants:

  • E-certificate of participation

column11: International School Of Business And Media, Bangalore
column45:
National Innovation Challenge – Event Overview:

  • A national-level innovation challenge for final-year engineering students to showcase prototypes, research, and real-world engineering solutions.
  • Includes prototype demos, jury evaluation, networking, mentorship, and awards.
  • Venue: ISB&M Bangalore
  • Date: 20 December 2025

Eligibility:

  • Open to final-year engineering students from all streams (Mechanical, Electrical, AI, Computer Science, etc.).
  • Participation modes:
  • Individual
  • Teams of up to 4 members
  • Registration Fee: 199 per team

Event Categories (Project Topics):

  • Core Engineering Innovations
  • Emerging Technology & Digital Solutions
  • Sustainability, Green Tech & Bio-Engineering
  • Interdisciplinary & Social Impact Innovations

Event Format / Rounds:

  • Live Prototype Presentation (On-Campus)
  • Presentation of working prototypes
  • Q&A with jury
  • Demonstration of implementation and impact
  • After registration, each team must submit a project write-up (description).

Evaluation Criteria: Projects will be judged on:

  • Innovation & Originality
  • Technical Feasibility
  • Prototype Demo & Functionality
  • Social & Environmental Impact
  • Scalability & Market Viability
  • Presentation & Communication Clarity

Awards (Per Category):

  • First Prize: 25,000 
  • Second Prize: 15,000 
  • Third Prize: 10,000 
  • Best Guide / Mentor Award: 10,000
  • Total Prize Pool: 2,00,000

Rules & Regulations:

  • Participation is open only to final-year engineering students.
  • Teams may have up to 4 members, and cross-branch or cross-college teams are allowed.
  • Each team must submit a 1-page abstract during registration.
  • Final presentations must include an original working prototype or live system demo.
  • Teams must present physically on campus and follow safety protocols.
  • Presentation time: 8–10 minutes, followed by a Q&A round.
  • Presentations must cover: Problem, Methodology, Implementation, Market Impact, Scalability.
  • Hardware must be supported by the team’s own setup; software must be shown in a working executable or live demo.
  • Jury decisions are final.

column2: Skill Climax V1.0  Code the Future of Trust
column45:
Welcome to Skill Climax V1.0—The Ultimate Code Battle by TECHhelp4U

Unleash your potential in a strategy-focused online coding challenge!

About the Opportunity:

Are you ready to architect the next big disruption? Welcome to Skill Climax V1.0, the flagship hybrid hackathon designed to bridge the gap between academic theory and industry innovation. Hosted by TECHhelp4U, a premier student-driven tech community, this event is a call to arms for India’s most promising developers, designers, and problem-solvers.

This isn't just a competition; it is a launchpad. We are creating an ecosystem where code meets culture, allowing you to compete with the best minds from across the country.

 

Why Should You Participate?

We have analyzed what students truly value. Here is what makes Skill Climax V1.0 unmissable:

  • Hybrid Flexibility: Participate in the Ideation Round from your campus/home. Only the best teams travel for the Grand Finale.

  • Career Acceleration: Top teams gain direct access to Pre-Placement Offers (PPIs) and internship interviews with our hiring partners.

  • The Offline Experience: The Grand Finale in Bhopal isn't just about coding—it's 36 hours of networking, mentorship sessions, food, and high-energy competition.

  • Community Recognition: Showcase your skills on a platform driven by students, for students.

 

Competition Structure

Round 1: The Blueprint (Online)

  • Format: Submission of a Project Proposal (PPT).

  • Goal: Pitch your idea, tech stack, and feasibility.

  • Selection: The most viable and innovative ideas will be shortlisted.

Round 2: The Grand Finale (Offline)

  • Venue: Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh.

  • Format: 36-Hour Non-Stop Hackathon.

  • Goal: Turn your PPT into a working prototype. Code, debug, and deploy in real time before a panel of judges.

Eligibility Criteria

  • Students Only: Open to all B.Tech/B.E., BCA, MCA, and B.Sc. (CS/IT) students.

  • Year: Open to students from all years (1st to 4th year).

  • Team Size: 2 to 4 members per team.

  • Inter-College Teams: Allowed and encouraged!

 

Code of Conduct:

  • Fresh Code Only: You cannot bring pre-written code. You may use open-source libraries and APIs, but the core logic must be written during the hackathon.

  • Plagiarism: Any team found copying code or ideas from other teams will be instantly disqualified.

  • Professionalism: Maintain decorum at the venue. Harassment or misconduct will lead to immediate expulsion.

 

Innovate. Build. Conquer. Registrations are closing soon. Secure your spot in the ultimate tech showdown.

Don't miss out on the chance to showcase your skills and make a difference. Register now for Skill Climax V1.0 and embark on an unforgettable journey of innovation and collaboration!

column11: National Institute of Bank Institute Management, Pune
column45:
Have you always been curious about the world of stock markets and how it works? Would you like to try your hand at trading without risking any real money? Or do you wish to showcase your trading skills to the world? If your answer is yes, here’s the perfect opportunity for you!
Shar-E-Shah, a flagship virtual stock trading event under Adhikosh’25, brings you the adrenaline rush of real-time trading in a risk-free environment. Step into the shoes of a trader in this thrilling simulation event designed for all the Bulls and Bears out there. Experience the excitement of navigating through volatile markets, interpreting corporate actions, and managing your portfolio amid changing financial scenarios.

Join the WhatsApp group for further process- https://chat.whatsapp.com/BrGpqMkioFd0TqNk7tXSeK

Event Overview:

  • The event consists of two rounds — a virtual trading challenge followed by an on-campus finale at NIBM. The competition will test your market acumen, patience, research, and analytical skills in both simulated and real analytical settings.

Round 1: Virtual Trading Competition:

  • Mode: Online (via StockGro Platform)• Dates: 22nd December 2025 to 26th December 2025
  • Participation: Individual• Each participant will receive a virtual capital of 10,00,000 at the start.
  • Trading will be active during market hours (09:30 AM – 03:30 PM IST).• Participants must join the league before the event begins.
  • Winners will be ranked based on their net worth (cash + portfolio value) as displayed on the leaderboard.
  • The top 10 participants with the highest profits will qualify for Round 2.

Round 2: The On-Campus Finale (NIBM):

  • The top 10 traders from the virtual round will be invited to the NIBM campus for the ultimate finale. In this round, participants will demonstrate their analytical and technical knowledge in front of an expert panel. Each participant will be given a market segment — Equity or Currency — and will have to forecast its next movement using technical analysis tools.

The evaluation will be based on:

  • Accuracy of market forecasting
  • Depth of technical understanding
  • Presentation clarity and confidence
  • Ability to justify analysis logically

A special guest from the Chartered Market Technician (CMT) community will grace the event. All finalists will be awarded exclusive CMT participation certificates in collaboration with NIBM.

Guidelines:

  • Only individual participation is allowed.
  • Participants must join the StockGro league before the event begins.
  • Round 1 will be held online, and Round 2 will be conducted on campus.
  • Jury decisions will be final and binding in all matters.
  • The top 3 participants from the final round will be declared winners of Shar-E-Shah 2026.
  • Tip from Rakesh Jhunjhunwala: “Hold on to a stock only if it will give returns, and not get emotionally attached to it. Respect the market. Have an open mind. Know what to stake. Know when to take a loss. Be responsible.”

column45:
InnovateX Pitch 2026 is the flagship high-stakes pitching battle of E-Summit, built to spotlight bold, visionary, and scalable tech-driven ideas from student innovators. The event pushes teams to think fierce, build smart, and pitch with clarity in a fast-paced, high-pressure arena.

With an AI-powered evaluation round that brings a Shark-Tank-style intensity, participants face real investor-like scrutiny even before reaching the main stage. Every team must deliver a technology-powered solution that solves a real-world problem with impact, feasibility, and scale.

Intense competition, limited pitch time, and a charged judging environment make InnovateX Pitch 2026 a thrilling launchpad for the next generation of breakthrough founders.

Round 1 – AI-VC Pitch Round (Online):

Sign-in on the website, find InnovateX Pitch in Competitions and complete team registration

Hosted on https://pitchdesk.in/ (Pitchdesk Website)

Format:

  • 5-day pitching window hosted on the official platform partner Pitchdesk Website
  • Each registered team receives a single 20-minute slot to pitch to the AI Venture Capital (AI-VC) system.
  • AI-VC evaluates teams on:
  • Problem and market opportunity
  • Solution and innovation
  • Business model and scalability
  • Team capability and execution
  • Traction and validation
  • Pitch quality and communication
  • A live leaderboard displays team rankings throughout the 5 days.
  • The top 25 teams qualify for the offline Grand Finale.

Guidelines:

  • The Team Leader must create the team and add members on the website.
  • All members must accept their email invites to join.
  • All participants must have an account on the platform.
  • Only the Team Leader can pitch.
  • One pitch per team; no retries.

Purpose:

  • Ensures fairness and transparency.
  • Provides real-time competitive insights.
  • Offers investor-style, AI-generated feedback early in the process.

Round 2 – Grand Finale (Offline):

  • Qualified Teams: Top 25 from Round 1
  • Venue: IIIT Nagpur

Format:

  • Live pitching session before an expert judging panel.
  • Each team receives:
  • 5 minutes for the presentation
  • 5 minutes for judges’ questions
    Total: 10 minutes per team

Reverse Pitch:

  • After each pitch, judges briefly explain:
  • How they would refine or strengthen the idea
  • Recommendations for business model improvements
  • Ways to scale or optimise execution
  • This adds a mentorship-oriented, learning-driven component to the event.

Prototype Interaction Zone (Optional):

  • Teams with working prototypes or products may showcase them.
  • Judges and audience may interact with the prototype before or after the pitch (with prior notice).
  • Helps strengthen idea validation and demonstration impact.

Evaluation Criteria:

  • Market potential
  • Business strategy
  • Revenue model
  • Product feasibility
  • Pitch delivery and clarity
  • Weighted score from the AI-VC Round 1

New Additions in InnovateX Pitch 2026:

  • Introduction of AI VC Pitching Round (virtual AI-based evaluation).
  • Live leaderboard for transparent and engaging competition.
  • Reverse Pitch segment for expert-driven refinement.
  • Dedicated Prototype Zone for teams to showcase demos or models.

Who Can Participate:

  • Students from any college across India.
  • Team size: 2 to 6 members.
  • Cross-college and cross-discipline participation allowed.
  • One student may join only one team.
  • Open to undergraduate, postgraduate, diploma, and PhD students from recognized institutions.
  • Plagiarized or copied ideas will result in disqualification.

Rules and Regulations:

  • Decisions of judges and the organizing team are final.
  • Any form of plagiarism leads to immediate disqualification.
  • There will be a small fees for the offline round.
  • Teams must strictly adhere to time limits.
  • Misconduct or violation of event policies will not be tolerated.

column11: Indian Institute of Technology, Banaras Hindu University (IIT - BHU)
column45:
CaseX is a dynamic case study competition where teams step into the shoes of entrepreneurs to solve real business challenges. Compete as part of themed houses with unique superpowers (tentative) , craft bold strategies, and showcase your creativity, analysis, and decision-making skills in an exciting entrepreneurial journey.

Event Details:

  • Solve and present solutions for startup problem statements (e.g., finance, funding, branding).
  • Consistent teams (1-4 members) required throughout the competition.
  • Final round is offline with paid passes.

Eligibility:

  • Open to all (students, professionals, entrepreneurs).
  • Cross-college teams allowed; one individual can join one team only.

Submission Guidelines:

  • Four-slide PDF named "TeamName_CaseX" , (excluding cover slide, appendix and references)
  • One submission per team.

column11: Indian Institute of Technology, Banaras Hindu University
column45:
Venture Verse is a dynamic competition that deepens participants’ understanding of venture capital and startups. It begins with a quiz on innovation, investment, and entrepreneurship, followed by an investment memo based on a real-world case study, and concludes with an offline pitch to a judging panel. The event aims to foster critical thinking, creativity, and strategic decision-making, offering a platform for aspiring entrepreneurs and investors to showcase their skills in the startup ecosystem.

General Guidelines:

  • The Quiz will be held online through unstop.
  • Team members can be from different colleges as well.
  • A person cannot be a member of more than one team.
  • Teams who fail to attend the quiz will not be considered for the next rounds.
  • Any team found violating the guidelines or the rules of the competition is liable to disqualification.
  • The decision of the organizers will be final and binding on all the participants.
  • In case of any queries, feel free to reach out to the organizers.

Judging Criteria for Venture Verse:

  • Accuracy & Knowledge – Correctness of responses and understanding of core concepts.
  • Speed & Time Management – Efficient use of time across all tasks.
  • Research & Analysis – Depth and quality of insights from data or case studies.
  • Feasibility – Practicality and realism of proposed ideas or solutions.
  • Innovation & Creativity – Originality and uniqueness in approach or recommendations.
  • Clarity & Structure – Logical organization and clear communication of ideas.
  • Presentation Skills – Confidence, delivery, and audience engagement.
  • Crisis Management & Problem-Solving – Composure under pressure and effective handling of unexpected challenges or questions.

Eligibility Criteria:

  • Team Size: 1-3 students.
  • Open to all including undergraduate or postgraduate students, professionals, entrepreneurs and others interested.
  • Cross college teams are allowed.
  • An individual can be a part of one team only.

column45:
The Design Challenge at nVisionX’26, organized in collaboration with the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC), invites innovators, designers, and technologists to reimagine urban waste management using technology, data, and system design. Participants will address a real civic problem by developing an optimized, data-driven routing and scheduling model for waste collection from GVPs to SCTPs, leveraging authentic GHMC datasets to drive operational efficiency, sustainability, and improved resource utilization.

Rewards and Benifits:

  • Prizes worth 50,000
  • Certificates from Elan & nVision, IIT Hyderabad and GHMC
  • Exclusive networking opportunities

Eligibility:

  • Open to students and professionals across India
  • Team size: 1–5 members
  • Participants may join only one team

Rules:

  • Solutions must address the official challenge statement.
  • All submissions must be original and developed during the competition.
  • Plagiarism or use of pre-built projects will result in disqualification..
  • Shortlisted teams will present their solutions in the Grand Finale (Hybrid) at IIT Hyderabad (in offline mode).

Problem Statement : The problem statement has been uploaded in the mid-term report round. Following is the link to the dataset: Dataset

column45:
About WealthWise:

The Finance and Investment Club of Miranda House invites students from across Delhi University to contribute to its Annual Journal- “WealthWise”.
 This publication serves as a platform for students to express their research, analysis, and innovative thought on issues shaping the world of finance today.

Theme: Frontiers of Finance: Where money meets everything else

Finance has evolved far beyond its traditional scope- it now thrives at the crossroads of technology, policy, culture, ethics, and philosophy.
 The theme “Frontiers of Finance” captures this multidimensional evolution, encouraging participants to explore how financial systems and ideas interact with the wider world.

Possible Areas of Exploration:

  • Financial innovation and emerging technologies (AI, blockchain, fintech)
  • Ethical finance, sustainability, and inclusive growth
  • Influence of culture, behavior, and policy on financial decision-making
  • Intersections of finance with governance, justice, and human values

At its core, this year’s theme reflects the idea that finance no longer exists in isolation- it is an integral force connecting economies, people, and ideas.

Categories of Submission:

Research Papers:

  • Word Limit: 200–250 words
  • Deadline: 10 December 2025
  • Should summarize the research topic, objective, methodology, and key insights
  • Final Paper Submission: 15 January 2026
  • Word Limit: 2000–5000 words
  • Ideal for in-depth, data-backed analysis or interdisciplinary studies related to the theme.

Research Articles / Book Reviews / Opinion Pieces:

  • Word Limit: 500–1200 words
  • Submission Deadline: 15 January 2026
  • Ideal for concise explorations, commentary, or thought pieces within the thematic scope.

Guidelines:

  • Open to students of all years from all universities
  • Cross-college teams allowed; no limit on entries from the same college
  • Individual or team submissions (up to 3 members) permitted

Formatting & Citation Requirements:

  • Font: Calibri or Times New Roman
  • Font Size:
  • Headings – 14 pt
  • Body Text – 12 pt
  • Spacing: 1.15
  • Citation Style: APA
  • File Format: PDF
  • All visuals must be clear, labelled, and properly sourced (hyperlink or reference link below each visual)

File Naming Format: Name_College_Category_Title
(Example: ABC_MirandaHouse_ResearchPaper_FintechAndEthics)

Rules:

  • AI usage must not exceed 15%; plagiarism must remain below 10%, entries exceeding these limits will be disqualified.
  • Interdisciplinary perspectives are welcome, but the core analysis must stay focused on finance

Publication:

  • Selected entries will be published in WealthWise, the annual journal of the Finance and Investment Club, Miranda House.

column2: Startup Street  The Entrepreneurial Gaming Arena
column45:
Event Description:

Startup Street is an interactive startup-themed gaming street where students transform into micro-entrepreneurs for a day. Participants set up game stalls, fun stalls, or earning-based experience stalls, each functioning like a mini-startup. Using a custom-developed digital app, buyers interact with stalls using a virtual currency system, creating a complete simulated economy.

The objective is to foster entrepreneurial thinking through real-time decision making, customer engagement, marketing strategies, and crisis-handling challenges introduced during the event.

Startup Street blends entrepreneurship, creativity, strategy, and fun into one dynamic street experience.

Event Highlights:

  • Run your own startup stall
  • Compete using virtual currency
  • Live leaderboard
  • Surprise crisis rounds every 45-60 minutes
  • Negotiations, marketing challenges & puzzles
  • Real money rewards through performance-based conversion
  • Buyers can redeem virtual money for real E-Cell merchandise

Event Structure:

Phase 1 – Registration & Setup:

  • Teams submit stall concepts
  • Space allotment by E-Cell
  • App credentials provided
  • Initial virtual points are credited
  • Buyers receive initial wallet balance

Phase 2 – Street Opens (Main Gameplay):

  • Stalls start operations
  • Buyers move stall-to-stall using virtual currency
  • Sellers maximize profit through creativity, pricing & strategy
  • Live leaderboard displays top performers

Rewards include extra virtual currency or restored stability.

Phase 3 – Closing & Evaluation:

  • Virtual accounts freeze
  • Points tallied automatically

Winners selected based on points and performance

Prize Distribution Framework:

  • Threshold Calculation:Only stalls with total points above the threshold qualify.
  • Formula: Threshold = (Total money spent) / (Total Stalls)
  • 2. Prize Pool Distribution: Only qualifying stalls share the prize pool.
  • Base Value: Base Value = Total Prize Pool / Sum of points of all qualifying stalls
  • Final Reward: Final Amount = Stall Points × Base Value

Awards & Recognition:

  • Most Profitable Startup (Stall)
  • Best Customer Engagement
  • Most Innovative Stall Idea

Eligibility:

  • Open to all students.
  • Teams can consist of 1–4 members.

column45:
About the Event:

Rebranding Wars 2026: The Creative Crisis Room is an immersive design competition where participants take on the role of brand revival strategists.
Teams will select real companies or startups — successful or failed — and reimagine their brand identity, website, or app experience to make them more impactful, functional, and user-friendly.

This year, participants have complete freedom of choice to explore their creative strengths — whether they’re passionate about logos, web interfaces, or app experiences.

Eligibility & Team Structure:

  • Open to all college students across India.
  • Teams can have 2 to 5 members.
  • Cross-college and cross-specialization teams are allowed.
  • Each participant can be part of only one team.
  • Any violation of these rules will result in disqualification.

Round 1 – Case Study Submission (Online):

WhatsApp Group Link: https://chat.whatsapp.com/FRBgBmOKSe706gM9cSj284?mode=wwt

Challenge Overview:

  • Round 1 challenges participants to think like a brand strategist and designer.
  • Each team must select an existing company, startup, or brand (successful or failed) and creatively rebrand one key element of its identity.

Teams are free to choose any one of the following:

  • Logo Redesign – re-imagine the brand’s visual identity.
  • Website Homepage Redesign – re-think the digital first impression of the brand.
  • App Homescreen Redesign – craft an improved mobile experience for users.

Participants should clearly explain why they chose the brand and how their redesign solves a real-world problem or elevates the brand’s image.

Note:

Judging parameters will differ slightly for each category (logo, website, or app) to ensure fairness, but the core focus remains on creativity, research depth, and overall design impact.

Submission Format:

Each team must submit a single, well-structured PPT or PDF (mandatory).

The presentation should include:

  • Slide 1 is mandatory and must clearly include:

    • Team Name

    • Team Members

    • Chosen Category (Logo / Website / App)

    • Selected Brand / Company

  • Apart from the first slide, there are absolutely no restrictions.

    • No fixed structure

    • No minimum or maximum slide count

    • No prescribed flow

    • No mandatory sections

Present your work however you want, wherever you want, and in whatever order you want.

However, participants must clearly communicate:

  • What was wrong

  • What was changed

  • Why it was changed

Read This Carefully:
Evaluation will NOT be influenced by:

  • Slide aesthetics

  • Fancy layouts

  • Animations

  • Transitions

  • Storytelling gimmicks

A visually attractive presentation will not compensate for weak design thinking, poor problem understanding, or shallow execution.

Focus on design quality and clarity, not decoration.

Optional Supporting Files:

  • Figma / design source files (optional but encouraged).
  • Additional visuals (JPEG, PNG, or PDF format).

Timeline:

  • Round 1 Start: 6 December 2025
  • Soft Deadline: 28 December 2025

Judging:

  • Entries will be judged on creativity, problem understanding, execution, and brand coherence.
  • Evaluation will differ slightly for each redesign type (logo / website / app) to ensure fairness.
  • Top-performing teams will qualify for the Grand Finale (Offline) at IIIT Nagpur.

Round 2 – Grand Finale (Offline):

Challenge Overview:

The Grand Finale brings the best teams face-to-face for a high-energy, on-campus design sprint. Finalists step into the role of brand strategists under pressure—they’ll tackle a real-world brand scenario, craft bold visual redesigns, and respond to unexpected challenges in real time.

Participants will receive a detailed Brand Scenario Brief at the start of the round describing the company’s background, target audience, and challenges.

Their task is to create:

  • a core visual redesign (logo, homepage, or app homescreen), and
  • a supporting brand element such as a quick campaign concept, tagline, or social-media preview that strengthens the redesign’s story.

Halfway through the event, a “Crisis Twist” will be announced—forcing teams to adapt their concept to new conditions such as a market shift, target-audience change, or PR setback.

Deliverables:

Teams must submit the following before the deadline:

  • Redesign File / Presentation Deck – showing their process, final designs, and how they adapted to the twist.
  • Figma or Design File Link – optional, view-only access recommended.
  • Short Pitch (3–5 minutes) – explain concept, response to twist, and key takeaways to judges.

Judging Overview:

  • Creativity and originality of the redesign.
  • Practicality, coherence, and alignment with the scenario.
  • Adaptability and problem-solving under the Crisis Twist.
  • Clarity and professionalism of presentation.
     (Specific scoring parameters will be disclosed only to registered finalists.)

General Rules & Guidelines:

  • Compliance:
    • All participants must strictly follow the rules and guidelines provided by the organizing committee.
    • Non-compliance may lead to disqualification.
  • Originality & Ethics:
    • Participants must ensure all submitted designs are 100% original.
    • Plagiarism, copying from online sources, or use of third-party assistance is strictly prohibited.
  • Team Composition:
    • Each team can have 2 to 5 members.
    • A participant can be part of only one team.
  • Equipment & Tools:
    • Participants must bring their own laptops or design equipment for offline rounds.
    • Use of any specific software or tools as required by the problem statements is mandatory.
    • In case of unavailability, participants may use alternative resources only as permitted by organizers.
  • Organizer Authority:
    • The organizing committee reserves the right to modify, interpret, or enforce rules at any stage of the event.
    • All decisions by the organizers and judges are final and binding.
    • This includes decisions on submissions, eligibility, judging, and dispute resolution.
  • Round 1 Submission Rules:
    • Teams must submit a comprehensive PPT/PDF case study covering research, ideation, and final redesign.
    • Optional Figma/source files may be attached as supporting material.
    • Ensure all submission links are accessible to judges.
  • Round 2 Submission Rules:
    • Teams must submit a Figma/design file link in presentation format, covering all aspects: research, problem identification, wireframes, prototypes, and final solution.
    • Short presentations or pitches may be conducted as per the event flow.
  • Code of Conduct:
    • Participants must maintain professionalism, respect, and decorum during the event.
    • Participants must adhere to IIIT Nagpur campus policies during the offline round.
  • Dispute Resolution:
    • The organizing committee reserves the right to resolve any disputes, ambiguities, or unforeseen situations in the best interest of the event.
  • Miscellaneous:
    • All teams must complete their submissions within the stipulated deadlines.
    • There will be a small registration fees for the final round.
    • No late submissions will be considered unless explicitly allowed by the organizers.

column45:
About the Event:

  • BizCon 2026 is a high-intensity corporate boardroom simulation inspired by MUN-style procedures, where Pizza Hut and Domino’s function as two competing committees.
  • Participants take on executive roles, engage in structured boardroom discussions, create unified company budgets, resolve financial crises, negotiate with stakeholders, and face live press—replicating real corporate strategy and leadership challenges.

Perks for all participants:

  • Welcome Kit + Lunch on both days + Snacks during sessions.

What We’re Looking For:

  • Strategic thinkers who can plan, negotiate, and justify financial decisions.
  • Leaders capable of handling high-pressure corporate crises.
  • Strong communicators with clarity and diplomacy.
  • Team players who can collaborate to lead Domino’s or Pizza Hut to success.

Key Details:

  • Committees: Domino’s vs Pizza Hut (two full corporate boards)
  • Each company has 20–25 executives (CEO, CFO, CTO, etc.)
  • Roles and role briefs will be informed 4–5 days prior to the event.
  • Each company starts every financial year with 50 S-Points (1 S-Point = $10 Million USD).
  • Simulation covers four financial years (two per day)
  • FY1 = mock year for training
  • FY2–FY4 = judged rounds
  • Each company prepares one unified annual budget
  • Unused S-Points roll over to next year
  • Crises generated by Backroom based on budget gaps. (Backroom analyzes budgets, designs crises, acts as stakeholders, and manages event dynamics.)

Eligibility & Team Structure:

  • Open to all college students across India
  • Individual participation only (no teams)
  • Participants are randomly assigned to Pizza Hut or Domino’s
  • Mandatory attendance on both days
  • Judges & Chairperson’s decisions are final

Timeline:

  • Day 1 – 16th January 2026
    • Session 1: 9:00 AM – 12:30 PM
    • Lunch Break: 12:30 PM – 01:30 PM
    • Session 2: 01:30 PM – 05:00 PM
  • Day 2 – 17th January 2026
    • Session 1: 9:00 AM – 12:30 PM
    • Lunch Break: 12:30 PM – 01:30 PM
    • Session 2: 01:30 PM – 05:00 PM

Evaluation Rules and Guidelines:

  • Winners selected based on total scores from FY2–FY4
  • Judging Criteria:
    • Budget Accuracy – 25%
    • Crisis Handling – 25%
    • Strategy – 20%
    • Diplomacy – 15%
    • Professionalism – 15%
  • One consolidated budget per company each financial year
  • Active crisis engagement is mandatory
  • Chairperson’s decisions are final

General Rules & Guidelines:

  • Strict adherence to rules and instructions
  • All documents must be original and created during committee
  • Domino’s & Pizza Hut prepare separate unified budgets
  • Bring personal laptop + stationery
  • No external help or pre-made templates
  • Maintain formal attire & decorum
  • Chairperson & Backroom have ultimate authority
  • All disputes resolved by the organizing committee

Judging Overview:

  • Only FY2–FY4 performance is scored
  • FY1 is purely a mock learning round
  • Participants judged individually despite collective decision-making
  • Final Criteria:
    • Crisis Management – 25%
    • Budget Logic & Accuracy – 25%
    • Strategic Thinking – 20%
    • Diplomacy & Negotiation – 15%
    • Professionalism – 15%

Presentation / Submission Requirements:

  • Participants must submit during the event:
    • Unified Annual Budget Sheet (50 S-Points system)
    • Crisis Response Directives
    • Press Conference Statements
    • Final Annual Company Report

WhatsApp Group Link: https://chat.whatsapp.com/LAExbttKWqE4ho9JC7scHN

column45:
Event Overview:

Tatva: The Case Competition is the flagship national-level case competition organised by the Case Quest Club at LBSIM Delhi. It aims to bring together top MBA and PGDM minds from across India to solve challenging, real-world business problems.
Through three progressive rounds, participants will demonstrate analytical rigour, structured thinking, and strategic clarity.

The competition provides a fair and engaging platform for learning, networking, and recognition.

Objective of the Event:

  • To promote a strong case-solving culture among management students.
  • To provide a platform for participants to analyse, ideate, and present innovative solutions to complex business issues.
  • To enhance inter-college engagement and strengthen LBSIM’s brand presence in the B-school circuit.
  • To identify and reward the best analytical and problem-solving minds through a competitive platform.

Eligibility:

  • Open to MBA/PGDM students from institutes across India.
  • Team size: 1–2 members (Cross-college teams allowed).
  • Each participant may be part of only one team.

Event Structure:

Round 1 – Preliminary Online Quiz (Elimination Round)

  • Objective-based quiz on business, strategy, and current affairs.
  • Conducted on the Unstop platform.
  • Top-performing teams qualify for Round 2.

Round 2 – Case Study Round

  • Selected teams will receive a real-world case problem.
  • Teams must submit their strategic solutions and presentations within a stipulated timeframe.

Round 3 – Grand Finale (On-Campus / Virtual)

  • Top 8–10 teams will present their solutions to a panel of judges from industry and academia.
  • Evaluation based on creativity, feasibility, financial analysis, and presentation quality.

column2: Strategic Minds: The Business Simulation Challenge
column11: 11/07 Dwarka Sector 11, near Metro Station, New Delhi, Delhi 110075
column45:
Strategic Minds is an interactive business simulation game designed to test participants’ strategic, analytical, and decision-making skills. The event will invite teams from various colleges to participate and compete in a simulated business environment.

  • Each team will be provided with an initial setup and a set of business situations that evolve across multiple rounds.
  • Teams will have to make key decisions related to marketing, operations, finance, and IT within a fixed budget.
  • At the end of every round, teams will receive the results of their decisions in terms of growth, profitability, and market performance.
  • The event aims to replicate real-world business challenges, encouraging participants to think critically, adapt quickly, and make data-driven decisions.

column11: 11/07 Dwarka Sector 11, near Metro Station, New Delhi, Delhi 110075
column45:
About the Opportunity:

  • Tatva proposes the Cultural Quiz & Crossword Fiesta 2026, an interactive cultural activity celebrating India’s heritage, art, cinema, literature, and traditions
  • The crossword will serve as a fun warm-up activity
  • The main competitive segment will be the Cultural Quiz

Warm-Up Crossword (Non-Competitive):

  • A simple cultural crossword to engage participants before the main quiz

Cultural Quiz (Competitive):

  • Teams of 2–3 members
  • Three rounds covering culture, festivals, cinema, art, and audio-visual clues
  • Winners selected based on cumulative scores

Venue:

  • The event will take place on campus at Lal Bahadur Shastri Institute of Management, Delhi

column2: Pitch Perfect - The Mad Ad Challenge
column11: Lal Bahadur Shastri Institute of Management
column45:
"Pitch Perfect: The Mad Ad Challenge" is an exciting and interactive event where paticipants must transform into advertisers for one day.

  • Teams will receive random, quirky, or completely absurd product ideas (e.g., Toothpaste for Dogs, Invisible Shoes, or Wi-Fi Perfume) and will have to design and present a convincing 1-minute advertisement pitch.
  • The challenge lies in how creatively, humorously, and persuasively they can “sell the impossible.”
  • The event blends debating skills (persuasion) with literary creativity (original ideas, slogans) and theatrics (presentation and performance) — embodying the very essence of Plithos.

column11: 11/07 Dwarka Sector 11, New Delhi, Delhi, India
column45:
Quiz Round

Participants are put to the ultimate test with real consulting-based quiz questions.
This quiz will consist of 30 questions to be completed in 20 minutes. Only the team leader will be attempting the quiz. 

Executive Summary Submission

Shortlisted teams will be given a global brand and a completely new product category to enter. Your task is to build a sharp and strategic Brand Pivot Strategy that reimagines how the brand can expand into this unfamiliar space 2-slider summary presentation.

Final Case Presentation

The shortlisted teams will submit their detailed solution and an on-campus pitch (underlining the assumptions, approach, solution, implementation, and other deliverables mentioned in the detailed problem statement document). The top teams will be evaluated on the basis of the 6-8 slider presentation in front of the jury.

column45:
Are you a Meme-lord?:

  • Do you save the most rad memes and then share them with your friends on whatsapp?
  • Do you look at random expressions of people and think, "ye to masst meme material hai"?
  • If the answer to any of these questions is yes, this quiz is definitely for you.
  • Presenting the third edition of Quizarc's meme themed quiz: The Grand Meme Quiz 4.0.

Details:

  • You need to follow Quizarc on Instagram to be eligible for the quiz.
  • The quiz will start sharp at 8 PM on 21st December 2025 (Sunday).
  • The quiz would be completely online and there are no registration fees.
  • Other details will be shared on Quizarc's Instagram page and your registered Email ID.
  • Cash prize for the winner!
  • Stay tuned to our Instagram page for details.

column45:
Event Overview: The Startup Survival Games was a multi-round elimination competition designed to test the  most crucial, non-technical skills required for entrepreneurial success: discipline, resource  management, high-stakes pitching, and sheer resilience. The event successfully merged  high-tension, physically demanding challenges with core business concepts. It started with over 100 participants, ensuring only the smartest and most adaptable startups survived the gauntlet. 

Eligibility Criteria: 

  • Open to all from any discipline in any college based out of India. 
  • Participants can register individually. 
  • The Participant should be students currently enrolled in a degree/diploma course  (part-time or full-time) from any discipline in any college based out of India. 
  • Any deviation from the above-mentioned guidelines will result in the immediate  disqualification of the entire team. 

Competition Structure: The Startup Survival Games is a multi-round elimination competition with each round based on a  explicitly designed to test the most crucial, non-technical skills required for entrepreneurial success: discipline, resource management, high-stakes pitching, and sheer resilience. The event successfully merged high-tension, physically demanding challenges with core business concepts, consisting of Squid Game like multiple rounds which test the physical and stress handling skills of participants. It started with over 100 participants, ensuring only the smartest and most adaptable startups survived the gauntlet.

column45:
Event Overview:

Experience the thrill of simulated stock market trading in this online event. Participants will gain practical exposure to financial markets, investment strategies, and risk management.
Each participant will receive a virtual portfolio of 10,00,000 to trade under real-time market conditions—with zero financial risk.

Special Benefit: Every participant gets 1-month FREE premium subscription for interview preparation worth 1000.

Whatsapp Group : Join here

 Guidelines:

  •  Eligibility: Open to all college students.
  •  Participation: Individual entry only.
  •  Event Schedule: The trading event will start from 12th jan 2026 (9:35 AM) to 19th jan 2026 (03:25   PM).
  •  Trading hours: Daily from 09:35 AM to 03:25 PM.

Note :

Login and Registration Information for the trading account on the online platform (StockGro) will be communicated to the registered participants through Whatsapp so kindly join the group from above link.

 Rules:

  •  Trading Period: The simulation will be active throughout the event duration.
  •  Trading Funds: Participants will use virtual money (10,00,000) with no additional funds provided.
  •  Ranking: Based on the portfolio value at the end of the simulation.
  •  Disqualification: Any form of manipulation or use of external tools will lead to disqualification. In case of disputes, the organizers' decision will be final and binding.
  •  Event Structure: The format, structure, and prize details may change before the event begins.
  •  Terms & Conditions: E-summit reserves the right to modify these rules at any time. All decisions made by the organizers will be final and binding on all participants. By entering the competition, participants agree to abide by all rules and conditions. E-summit also reserves the right to alter the prize distribution and any competition rules as needed.
  • Participation certificate will be provided only to those who register in the StockGro Link provided in the description box.

Note:
The Top 30 participants (to be announced later) must submit a document outlining their trading strategy. The organizer will independently verify each candidate and their submissions. Any participant found guilty of misrepresentation or malpractice will be immediately disqualified.

Judgment Parameter:
The participant’s performance will be evaluated based on the highest profit generated through their trading decisions.

column45:
The "Presentation Pro Quiz" is an inter-college competition designed to test and enhance participants' presentation skills. It provides a platform for individuals to showcase their abilities in various aspects of effective communication.

The Quiz Will Consist of Two Rounds:

Round 1: Multiple Choice (Theoretical & Analytical):

  • This round will assess participants' knowledge of presentation principles, techniques, and best practices.
  • It will include multiple-choice questions.
  • Duration: 10 minutes.
  • Number of Questions: 20 questions.

Round 2: Practical Presentation Challenge (Application):

  • Participants will be given a problem statement or topic in advance (via email - check your emails).
  • They will have a limited time to prepare and deliver a short presentation.
  • Preparation Time: 15 minutes.
  • Presentation Time: 5 minutes, followed by a 2-minute Q&A session.
  • Judges will score based on the skills mentioned above.

Rules:

  • Eligibility: Open to undergraduate and postgraduate students from all disciplines.
  • Team Composition: Participants can participate individually or in teams of two.
  • Inter-college teams: Allowed.
  • Inter-specialization teams: Allowed.
  • Language: Presentations must be delivered in English.
  • Visual Aids: Participants may use simple visual aids (e.g., a few slides) during the practical round.
  • Time Limits: Strict adherence to time limits is mandatory. Exceeding the time limit will result in penalties.
  • Originality: All content presented must be original. Plagiarism will lead to disqualification.
  • Judging Criteria: Judges' decisions are final and binding.
  • Device Usage: In round 2, the use of external devices for internet access is prohibited during the preparation time. Participants may use their own laptops for presentation delivery.
  • Respectful Conduct: Participants must maintain a respectful and professional demeanor throughout the competition.
  • Technical Issues: Organizers are not responsible for individual technical issues.

Process:

  • Registration: Participants must register online or through the designated registration desk.
  • Round 1 (Written): Participants will take a written test covering presentation theory and analysis.
  • Round 1 Results: Top performers from Round 1 will advance to Round 2.
  • Round 2 (Practical): Participants will receive a problem statement and deliver a presentation.
  • Judging and Scoring: A panel of judges will evaluate presentations based on predefined criteria.
  • Winners Announcement: Winners will be announced after the judges' deliberations.

Prizes:

  • Certificates of participation for all participants.
  • Prizes for the top three winners (cash/vouchers/trophy).

Guidelines for Participants:

  • Prepare thoroughly for both theoretical and practical aspects of presentations.
  • Practice delivering presentations within time limits.
  • Focus on clarity, conciseness, and audience engagement.
  • Be prepared to think on your feet and handle unexpected questions.
  • Ensure any visual aids are clear, and easy to read.

column2: Logistics League  The Ultimate Shipping Challenge
column11: 11/07 Dwarka Sector 11, near Metro Station, New Delhi, Delhi
column45:
Game Synopsis (Points Format):

  • Logistics League is a strategic, dice-based simulation game where teams act as shipping companies competing to deliver cargo efficiently.
  • The game focuses on essential logistics concepts such as route optimization, transport mode selection, cost control, and risk management.
  • Each team must transport four different cargo shipments across four rounds, making key business decisions to maximize profit.
  • Random events—like fuel price changes, delays, or unexpected cost savings—simulate real-world logistics disruptions.
  • Dice rolls determine cargo type, route options, and random events, adding unpredictability and excitement.
  • The team with the highest total profit at the end of all four rounds is declared the winner.

Game Objectives:

  • Develop a practical understanding of supply chain and logistics decision-making.
  • Strengthen strategic thinking and risk assessment skills.
  • Experience real-world transportation challenges in a competitive, engaging environment.
  • Promote teamwork, collaboration, and problem-solving under pressure.

column45:
To evaluate participants’ analytical thinking, data interpretation, and presentation skills by challenging them to derive actionable business insights from real-world datasets.

Round 1-Quiz:

  • A short quiz to assess basic analytical and business understanding.

Round 2-Rapid Insights

  • Teams receive a cleaned dataset and must identify key performance indicators
    (KPIs), trends, and anomalies.
  • Deliverable: A 1-page insight summary.

Round 3-Boardroom Pitch:

  • Teams will receive a case study and a dataset to create a dashboard or slide deck
    showcasing their analysis and recommendations. They will present their findings to a panel of three judges (faculty and industry experts).

column11: Lal Bahadur Shastri Institute of Management (LBSIM), New Delhi, Delhi, India
column45:
Event Overview:

  • Anumaan is the flagship annual case competition hosted by Cerebrate – The Strategy & Consulting Club of LBSIM.
  • Brings together top talent from leading B-schools and undergraduate institutions.
  • Participants compete in strategy, logic, and innovation through multiple progressive rounds.
  • Begins with an analytical screening round and concludes with a high-stakes Boardroom Case Presentation evaluated by faculty and industry experts.
  • Aimed at fostering problem-solving, critical thinking, and business acumen.
  • Provides a dynamic platform for inter-college engagement, visibility, and healthy competition.

Objectives:

  • Establish Cerebrate as a center of excellence in consulting and strategic thinking on campus.
  • Offer students a realistic case-solving experience mirroring consulting environments.
  • Maximize inter-college participation to drive engagement and strengthen brand presence.
  • Promote cross-functional thinking across strategy, finance, marketing, and operations.
  • Enhance LBSIM’s recognition through participation, media visibility, and institutional collaboration.

Event Structure:

  • Team Size: 3 members.
  • Eligibility: Open to all UG & PG students across colleges.
  • Registration Mode: Google Form (collecting team name, college name, member details, and college ID uploads).
  • Team Cap: Approximately 80–100 teams expected through inter-college outreach.
  • Shortlisting: Based on performance in Round 1.

column45:
Concept of the Competition:

  • Kairos 2025 is a premier national-level festival celebrating creativity, innovation, and entrepreneurship among undergraduate students across India.
  • Aligned with the vision of Skill India, the event challenges young minds with skills and mindset needed to drive the nation’s growth story.
  • It brings together engineering precision, marketing brilliance, analytical acumen, and creative expression.
  • Activities include quizzes, innovation challenges, creativity modules, and real-world pitch fests.
  • Participants are inspired to think boldly, act purposefully, and create impactful solutions.

Qualifying Criteria:

  • Students currently enrolled in any state-recognised/UGC/AICTE-recognized undergraduate college are eligible.
  • Team Size: Minimum team size is 2 and Maximum team size is 5.

Competition Rounds:

  • Initial Round (State-wise):
    • Teams submit an idea generation outlining innovation, usability, relevance, scalability, potential risks, and deployment plan.
    • Screening committee shortlists entries.
    • Round conducted online.
    • A Welcome kit and Certificate of Participation will be provided by FORE School of Management 
  • Second Round (Regional):
    • Locations: Delhi, Mumbai, Cochin, Kolkata, Guwahati, Jaipur, Varanasi, Ranchi, Chandigarh, Bhopal, Hyderabad/Bengaluru.
    • Shortlisted teams from First round will be asked to present their ideas shared in the initial round. This will include Idea generation and relevant Analysis.
    • Shortlisted will be given prizes- First prize - 10,000, Second Prize- 7,500 and Third Prize- 5,000.
  • Final Round (National Round in Delhi Campus):
    • Shortlisted Candidates from the second round will compete at National level.
    • Participants create a mock AV (like an AdMad) and present their idea to the jury in Delhi. Building of Prototype or app is optional.

We will be coming to your city between January 5 to 10, 2025. 

What Will We Be Offering:

  • Exciting cash prizes and goodies at all rounds.
  • Certificate of participation.
  • Mentorship support from FSM IIC for further execution.

column45:
The Verdict Arena merges entrepreneurship, global laws, and strategic reasoning. Participants step into the shoes of founders navigating complex international legal systems — learning how regulations can both empower and challenge startups. Through multiple rounds, they’ll test their business intellect, legal awareness, and persuasive skills in real-world startup scenarios.

Guidelines:

  • Teams will begin with an online quiz focused on global startup bylaws and international regulations.
    • Top scorers from this stage will move forward.
  • In the next stage, teams will analyze a startup case involving a bylaw loophole.
    • They must submit a strategic, legal, and profitable solution in PDF format.
    • Scores from this and the previous stage will be combined to determine advancement.
    • The top 10 teams will qualify for the final stage.
  • Finalists will take part in a structured debate exploring real-world legal and business challenges.
    • Combined scores from this stage and the previous one will determine the winners.

Eligibility Criteria:

  • Team Size: 1-2 Members
  • Open to all: Undergraduate, postgraduate students, professionals, and aspiring entrepreneurs.
  • Cross-college participation allowed.
  • Each participant can register only once.

Judging Criteria:

  • Legal & Business Understanding
  • Innovation & Feasibility
  • Analytical Thinking
  • Communication & Argument Strength
  • Presentation & Clarity

column45:
About us

Caf-Fin is a student-driven body at SIBM Pune that aims to promote Finance as a career option for students. As a special interest group, Caf-Fin works steadfastly to invoke curiosity and passion among the student community across various arenas of Finance. The club acts as a vital touchpoint between students and industry institutions, offering opportunities to broaden their understanding of financial markets through certifications, competitions, workshops, and events.

Finozine, the club’s flagship annual initiative, embodies this vision by providing a platform for thought leadership and meaningful dialogue in the world of finance.

Event Name: Finozine 4.0 - Annual Finance Magazine Article Writing Competition
Hosted by: Caf-Fin, The Finance Club of SIBM Pune

About the competition

Caf-Fin, the Finance Club of SIBM Pune, proudly presents the fourth edition of its flagship annual magazine - Finozine 4.0. This national-level article writing competition invites students, alumni, and finance professionals to contribute their perspectives on the theme - “Capital Connect: India’s Markets in Motion.”

The competition aims to encourage thoughtful discourse on India’s evolving financial landscape, highlighting the nation’s growing integration with global markets and the innovations shaping its capital ecosystem. Participants are invited to explore diverse dimensions - from the rise of GIFT City and rupee internationalisation to the emergence of tokenisation and the increasing participation of retail investors.

The most insightful and well-articulated articles will be featured in Finozine 4.0, showcasing ideas that capture the essence of India’s financial transformation.

Theme:

  • India’s Inclusion in Global Bond Indices: What global index inclusion means for inflows, yields, and credibility. How it transforms India’s bond market and investor base.
  • Rise of Domestic Capital: The power shift toward retail and mutual fund investors. How homegrown capital provides resilience amid global volatility.
  • IPO Boom and Capital Formation: The surge in listings across traditional and new-age sectors. How vibrant equity markets are fueling India’s growth story.
  • GIFT City: India’s Global Financial Gateway: The evolution of IFSC as a bridge between domestic and global markets. Can GIFT City position India as Asia’s next financial hub?
  • De-dollarisation and Rupee Internationalisation: The changing currency order: can the rupee find its global footing? How local-currency trade settlements could reshape cross-border capital.
  • Evolving Role of Institutional Investors: Pension funds, insurers, and sovereign wealth funds shaping long-term capital. Domestic institutions as stabilizers in volatile markets.
  • Fintech and Market Access: The role of digital platforms and fractional investing in democratizing finance. How AI and analytics are redefining investment strategies.
  • Tokenisation and the Future of Capital Markets: How tokenised assets could transform ownership, liquidity, and transparency. Bridging traditional finance with blockchain-based capital innovation.

Participants are encouraged to explore these sub-themes through analytical, research-oriented, or opinion-based perspectives, offering insights into how India’s capital markets are connecting to the world. Each participant is expected to choose one sub-theme from the list and present their insights and analysis exclusively on that topic.

Eligibility: 

  • Open to everyone

Rules:

  • Format for the article:
  • Font: Calibri, Font Size: 11
  • Line Spacing: 1.15
  • Word Limit: 1,000 - 1,500 words excluding charts, graphs, tables, and annexures
  • Only MS Word or PDF documents are accepted
  • A team can contribute only one article from the above list
  • Any number of entries permitted from a college
  • The entry should be new, original work, and all the data and references used must be mentioned in the article. Up to 5% of plagiarism is accepted. AI-generated content must not exceed 10% in any submission.
  • Naming Convention:Team Name_College Name

column45:
About Novartis: 

Novartis is a focused innovative medicines company. Every day, we work to reimagine medicine to improve and extend people’s lives so that patients, healthcare professionals and societies are empowered in the face of serious diseases. Our medicines reach more than 296 million people worldwide.

About Novartis in India:

Novartis has partnered India's healthcare journey since 1947. Today, India is one of the few countries in the world where Novartis has Research, Development, Commercial and Operations continuum. Our footprint includes Novartis Corporate Center and Genome Valley sites (Global Capability Center housing Biomedical Research, Development, and Operations teams) in Hyderabad and Novartis International (commercial operations) headquartered in Mumbai. In 2024, we also added a Development India Hub site in Mumbai.

We have two legal entities namely: Novartis Healthcare Private Limited and Novartis India Limited with over 9000 employees and a 38% diversity. We have been consistently recognised as a Top Employer in the country, are a certified Great Place to Work® and recently earned a spot among Best Workplace in Asia™ 2025.

Every day, we work to reimagine medicine to improve and extend people’s lives with our portfolio of innovative and established medicines in therapeutic areas including cardiovascular, oncology, immunology, eye care, and neurosciences. 

About Novartis Corporate Center

We were among the pioneers when we setup a Global Capability Centre in Hyderabad nearly two decades ago. Today, there are six such centers across the world, strategically spanning different time zones. Recently, named as the Novartis Corporate Centers (NOCC), the one located in Hyderabad is the largest and is fueling our purpose of reimagining medicine.

The centre is key to Novartis’ vision and provides high–quality support service across multiple functions and capabilities – Biomedical Research, Drug Development, Business Services, Data, Digital & IT, Manufacturing Supply and Quality, Procurement & Real Estate, Human Resources, Finance, Risk & Compliance, Legal, Communications & Engagement. We are one of the very few GCCs who have gone beyond the conventional tech-heavy presence to diversify into other areas where the talent pool availability in India can be tapped to drive enterprise value at scale.

About Novartis Development India Hub

The Novartis Global Development division is responsible for advancing our pipeline of investigational medicines, to bring transformative new treatment options to patients with serious diseases. It leads the clinical development of potential new medicines, running large clinical trials and generating evidence that turns molecules to medicines. The key hubs of this division are in Switzerland (Basel), the USA (East Hanover); and India (Hyderabad and Mumbai). The Development hub in India works on supporting global development projects to generate evidence and convert molecules to medicines.

The India hub has evolved over more than 20 years and today sees three vibrant state-of-the-art centres across two cities, Hyderabad - at the Novartis Corporate Center (NOCC) and Genome Valley, and a recent one in Mumbai. Today, the India hub is an important base to support the development journey of many breakthrough medicines across all therapy areas (cardiovascular renal metabolic, oncology, immunology, neuroscience). The India center supports all global functions including Global Clinical Operations, Technical R&D, Patient Safety and Pharmacovigilance, Regulatory Affairs, Advanced Quantitative Science, to name a few. The vast footprint of the Development division in India (~2,800 employees) is instrumental in supporting the company’s long-term growth and delivering on its purpose to improve and extend people’s lives.

For over 15 years, Novartis Technical R&D (TRD) has been increasing its footprint in Genome Valley, Hyderabad and currently 300+ scientists including Masters, PhDs and post doctorates are supporting the pharmaceutical development of new chemical entities.  The Indian scientists are providing support in the development of many chemical entities aligned with our focus therapies. The India hub provides impetus to bright leaders and also deepens its focus on drug development work.

*All Data as of May 2025

Eligibility: 

  • Participants can register in teams comprising 1 to 4 members.
  • For teams advancing to Round 2, it is mandatory to have a faculty mentor affiliated with the same institute or any other who will guide them in developing a working solution for the given use cases. The total team size, including the faculty mentor, must not exceed five members. 
  • All final and pre-final year students are eligible to participate in this engagement. 
  • Cross-organization teams are allowed. 
  • Cross-specialization teams are allowed. 
  • A participant cannot be a member of more than one team. 
  • Any deviation from the aforementioned rules will result in the immediate disqualification of the entire team. 

Competition Structure:

AMA Session 1

  • An interactive Ask Me Anything session connects teams with mentors and organizers for real-time guidance.
  • This will help participants understand the problem statements, overall structure, and guidelines, and to prepare them for abstract submission in the Innovation Challenge Submission Round.

Round 1: Innovation Challenge Submission Round

  • In this phase, all registered teams are required to submit an abstract deck in PDF or PPTX format that clearly presents their approach and methodology, model choice and setup, model training and evaluations, results and visualizations, and challenges and next steps.
  • If a team chooses multiple problem statements, they must submit separate abstract decks for each one.
  • This stage emphasizes clarity, feasibility of the proposed direction, and alignment with the evaluation criteria so reviewers can assess both innovation and practicality.
  • Maximum Slides (Report): 5
  • Evaluation Criteria
    • All submissions will be reviewed by a panel of domain experts.
    • Teams will be shortlisted based on:
      • Problem Understanding & Solution Design
      • Approach & Methodology
      • Feasibility & Practical Application
      • Quality, Clarity, and Depth of Presentation

AMA Session 2

  • An interactive Ask Me Anything session will be conducted for the teams shortlisted for the semi-finals.
  • This session will focus on helping teams refine their working solutions through mentor-led discussions on model optimization, result interpretation, and presentation clarity.
  • Participants will gain valuable insights to enhance the quality, robustness, and storytelling of their submissions for the upcoming round.

Round 2: Semi-Finals — Working Solutions Submission

  • The shortlisted teams must submit their final solutions in a specified format to ensure consistency and ease of evaluation.
  • For teams advancing to Round 2, it is mandatory to have a faculty mentor affiliated with the same institute or any other who will guide them in developing a working solution for the given use cases. 
  • Each solution should be packaged into a single zip file containing a detailed report and all the code necessary to reproduce the results, along with clear documentation of assumptions, approach, and how outcomes map to defined success metrics.
  • Building on the abstract, teams should present end-to-end execution, including model setup and training, evaluations aligned to stated metrics, results and visualizations, error analysis, known limitations, and proposed next steps.
  • The submission should be reproducible, well-structured, and transparent to facilitate rigorous review.

Round 3: Mentorship

  • The shortlisted finalist teams (9-15) shall undergo mentoring by our panel of experts to prepare for a final pitch to the Novartis leadership and SME panel.
  • During this stage, teams are expected to:
    • Enhance their proposed solutions based on mentor feedback
    • Deepen their analysis and technical execution
    • Prepare for the final presentation round
  • This round is designed to help participants bridge the gap between concept and implementation, ensuring that their ideas are both innovative and practically viable.

Round 4: Grand Finale

  • The finalist teams (9-15) will be invited to the Novartis Hyderabad Campus for the final pitch presentations.
  • The teams will pitch their ideas offline in front of an expert panel of judges, providing a unique opportunity to showcase their innovation, strategy, and potential in a dynamic, face-to-face setting. 
  • This round will test not only the strength of your idea but also your team’s ability to communicate and defend your vision under real-time scrutiny. 

What’s in it for you? 

  • All national finalists based on the assessment and purely on merit, may qualify to receive cash prizes from a total pool of INR 7,50,000 across all problem statements.*
  • All the National Finalists may get an opportunity to win PPIs from the Novartis team based on the evaluation criteria and at the sole discretion of Novartis.
  • Selected teams may get an opportunity to collaborate with Novartis on co-creating a solution, post-evaluation and closure of the competition.
  • Cash prize money is subject to applicable tax deductions.

*Terms & Conditions Apply. Refer to the T&C Document.

column11: RA Auditorium ,  Dr.M.G.R. Educational and Research institute, Poonamallee High Rd, Vishwas Nagar, Maduravoyal, Chennai,  Tamil Nadu 600095
column45:
Unleash your entrepreneurial spirit in this exciting innovation challenge!

About the Opportunity:

Get ready to ignite your entrepreneurial journey with the PITCH PREDACTOR THE RISE, presented by Dr mgr educational research institute. This offline innovation challenge is designed to empower teams to develop and pitch groundbreaking ideas in the realm of entrepreneurship, business plans, and presentations.Participants will gain invaluable experience in crafting compelling business plans and delivering persuasive presentations. This challenge is your platform to showcase your innovative ideas, hone your skills, and connect with like-minded individuals, all while making a mark in the world of entrepreneurship.

  • Organized by: Rotaract Club of Dr. M.G.R University
  • Incubation Partners: AKC & BETF

Eligibility Criteria

  • Open to all students from any college/university across India.
  • Team size: Individual/2-3 members per team.
  • All team members must be currently enrolled students.
  • Cross-college/cross-institution teams are allowed.
  • Each participant can be part of only ONE team.
  • Valid student ID may be required for verification.

Event Timeline:

 

Nov 11

Registration Opens

Nov 16 - Dec 7

Virtual Orientation Classes

Nov 30

Registration closes & Idea Submission Deadline

Dec 3

Top 10 Teams Announced

Dec 8

GRAND FINALE

 

Registration Details

Important: Registration is on a first-come, first-served basis. Limited slots available!

Registration Includes:

  • Access to all 5-6 orientation classes
  • Mentorship sessions
  • Event materials and resources
  • Participation certificate
  • Completion certificate (for attending all classes)
  • Access to alumni network

Presentation Format

  • Total time: 10 minutes
  • 5 minutes- Pitch Presentation
  • 5 minutes- Q&A with Investers - Judges (May extend to 10 min)

Presentation Format Guidelines:

Mandatory PPT Structure (10-15 Slides Maximum)

Your Presentation Must Inculde ,

  • Problem Statement
  • Existing Solutions
  • Your Solution
  • Product/Service Design
  • Unique Value Proposition (UVP)
  • TARGETTED AUDIENCE
  • Market Analysis.
  • SURVEY RESULTS (OPTIONAL).

Evaluation Criteria

  • Problem Impact & Relevance.
  • Feasibility & Scalability.
  • Innovation & Design Excellence.
  • Ease of Use & Accessibility.
  • Business Model & Market Analysis.
  • Presentation Quality.
  • Q&A Session Performance.

Rules & Regulations

  • Individual / team must consist of 2-3 members only.
  • All members must be currently enrolled students.
  • A team can submit only one startup idea.
  • Plagiarism of ideas will result in immediate disqualification.
  • The registration fee is non-refundable under any circumstances.
  • Teams must submit their presentation or pitch deck before the deadline provided.
  • Usage of offensive or inappropriate content during the presentation is strictly prohibited.
  • Judges' and mentors' decisions will be final and binding.
  • Teams must actively participate in workshops and masterclasses for continued eligibility.
  • All teams must maintain professional decorum and respect towards organizers and peer

column45:
Yantrautsav is an exciting event calling all aspiring innovators and young minds to showcase their creativity, passion, and robotics skills by exhibiting a fully functional robotics-related model. This challenge is designed to inspire creativity and innovation across all skill levels.

Guidelines & Eligibility:

  • Open to All: The competition is open to participants of all age groups and all skill levels – whether you are a beginner or an experienced creator.
  • Format: Participants are required to bring a fully functional robotics-related model for exhibition.

Objective:

  • Showcase innovative ideas and robotic creations.
  • Demonstrate the technology behind the creation and explain its working.
  • Solve real-world problems or introduce new concepts.

Prize Pool (Senior)

Position

Prize Amount

Total

60,000

1st Prize

25,000

2nd Prize

20,000

3rd Prize

15,000

 

Prize Pool (Junior)

Position

Prize Amount

Total

30,000

1st Prize

15,000

2nd Prize

10,000

3rd Prize

5,000

 

Robotics Application Domains

The following domains are applicable to both Junior and Senior categories, but projects are not limited to this list.

  • Sustainable Energy: Wind, hydroelectric, solar power, etc.
  • Task-performing Autonomous Projects: (e.g., autonomous robots, drones)
  • Subcategories: Outdoor Autonomous Projects, Indoor Autonomous Projects (e.g., smart home projects).
  • Examples: Arduino-based Snake Robot controlled using Android app, wall climbing robot, robotic vehicle controlled by hand gesture.
  • Task-performing Remote-controlled Projects
  • Agricultural Projects: Grass cutter, agribot, agricultural tasks.
  • Robotic Arms: Simple robotic arm, flex sensor arm, algorithm-based arm, Android-controlled arm, hand motion controlled arm.
  • Military Application Projects
  • Humanoid and Social Projects
  • Mechanical Education Projects:
  • Examples: Emergency braking system in four-wheeler, 8-leg spider robot using Theo Jansen linkage.
  • Aquatic Projects:
  • Examples: Solar lake pool cleaning drone, oil skimmer RC boat.
  • Medical Field-Related Projects
  • Swarm Projects
  • Educational Robotic Projects
  • Entertainment and Art Projects
  • Other Category (Please Specify)

Rules of the Competition:

  • Participants must exhibit a fully functional robotics-related model.
  • The model must be the participants' original creation/adaptation.
  • Participants must be prepared to demonstrate the technology and explain the working of their creation.

Evaluation Criteria:

Both leagues will be evaluated based on:

  • Design
  • Functionality
  • Presentation

Important Notes:

  • The Organizers reserve the right to modify or amend the competition rules at any time. Participants will be notified of any changes.
  • The decision made by judges is final and cannot be contested.

column45:
Purpose:

  • A scenario-based assessment designed to evaluate the strategic thinking of mid-to-senior level recruiters.
  • Goes beyond basic screening to assess how candidates manage complex hiring lifecycles and influence stakeholders.

What It Evaluates:

  • Handling real-world recruitment challenges.
  • Managing difficult hiring managers.
  • Creating sourcing strategies for niche roles.
  • Negotiating offers effectively.
  • Using data to improve hiring funnel efficiency.
  • Driving end-to-end talent acquisition strategy.

Assessment Nature:

  • Completely application-based, not theoretical.
  • Evaluates a recruiter's ability to:
  • Build a sustainable and high-quality hiring process.
  • Balance speed of hiring, candidate experience, and talent quality.
  • Demonstrate strategic and operational excellence in recruitment.
