column2: Anvakrit 2.0-  National Crime Scene Investigation Competition
column45:
Event Title:

  • Anvakrit 2.0: Unmask the Truth in Bytes

Competition Type:

  • National Crime Scene Investigation Competition (UG Level)
  • Organized by National Forensic Sciences University, Delhi Campus
  • Dates: 11th – 13th February 2026

About the Competition:

  • “The smallest detail is often the key to the biggest truth.”
  • After the tremendous success of its first edition, Anvakrit 2.0 returns — bigger, sharper, and more challenging.
  • This year, the competition extends across all domains of forensic expertise, including forensic science, criminology, forensic accounting, and law, with a special emphasis on cybercrime and digital forensics.
  • The theme, “Unmask the Truth in Bytes,” invites participants to tackle complex investigations that go beyond the traditional crime scene, venturing into the fast-evolving world where every click, transaction, and digital trace could hold the key to uncovering the truth.

Format & Rounds:

  • Round 1 – Case File Investigation (Online/Offline):
    • The competition kicks off with an intriguing case file testing your observation, logic, and forensic reasoning.
    • Teams will answer investigative questions within a limited time frame.
  • Round 2 – Poster Presentation of Findings (Online):
    • Present your findings through a creative and analytical poster explaining your investigative process and conclusions.
  • Round 3 – Workshops and Expert Lectures:
    • Go beyond theory and step into the field.
    • The hands-on workshops and lectures taught by leading experts from the world of forensics and criminology will provide practical skills and real-world experience, helping participants master the art and science of crime scene investigation.
  • Round 4 – On-Campus Crime Scene (Offline at NFSU Delhi):
    • Top teams will visit the NFSU Delhi Campus for expert sessions, lab visits, and a real-life crime scene investigation challenge integrating multiple forensic domains.
    • Surprises await from the very start of registration — awareness and adaptability will be tested throughout.

Eligibility:

  • Open to students of Classes 11–12 and Undergraduate programs (any stream).
  • Institutional/school ID card is mandatory during offline rounds.
  • No prior forensic experience required — curiosity, creativity, and teamwork are key!

Team Formation:

  • Teams of 4 members (self-formed).
  • No reshuffling or name changes after registration confirmation.

Registration Details:

  • Fee: 4,000 per team (includes registration kits, workshops & expert lectures, certificates, trophies/medals, and two meals per day for the event).
  • Accommodation (optional): 500 per person per day.
  • Registration Cap: 300 participants (first-come, first-serve).
  • Last Date: 20th December 2025.
  • Confirmation will be shared post-verification by the Organizing Committee.

Judging Criteria:

  • Round 1: Speed, accuracy, and analytical depth.
  • Round 2: Creativity, clarity, and forensic reasoning.
  • Round 4: Observation, teamwork, and practical application.
  • Judges will include faculty experts, professionals, and industry mentors from the field of forensics and law enforcement.

Prizes & Recognition:

  • Prize Pool: INR 1.2 Lakh.
  • Top 3 Teams will be awarded cash prizes and certificates.
  • All participants receive Certificates of Participation from NFSU.

Rules & Code of Conduct:

  • Follow all instructions issued by the Organizing Committee.
  • Any malpractice (tampering evidence, disturbing other teams, or unauthorized tools) will lead to immediate disqualification.
  • Respectful conduct towards judges, volunteers, and peers is mandatory.

Event Highlights:

  • Hands-on crime scene simulation experience.
  • Expert-led workshops and lab demonstrations.
  • Multi-disciplinary forensic exposure.
  • National-level recognition and networking.

column2: InsightsCraze  The Data Analyst Logic Challenge
column45:
InsightCraze is a focused, application-based quiz designed to test participants on real-world data thinking. This is not a basic-level test of definitions or formulas. Instead, it evaluates how participants reason through statistical problems, interpret datasets, apply SQL logic, and select appropriate forecasting methods.
Each question is built around practical challenges a data analyst might encounter. The quiz aims to assess analytical sharpness, attention to detail, and problem-solving ability across core concepts in data interpretation, regression, and time series analysis.
This challenge is best suited for individuals who are comfortable with analytical thinking and are ready to test their skills through tough-level questions that reflect real-world decision-making.

Guidelines:

  • This is an individual quiz and must be completed independently.
  • The challenge includes 5 multiple-choice questions.
  • All questions are application-based and reflect real-world data problems.
  • The duration for the quiz is 10 minutes (60 seconds per question).
  • Only one attempt is allowed per participant.
  • Use of external help, AI tools, or calculators during the quiz is not permitted.
  • The quiz is open to students, freshers, or self-learners with a background or interest in analytics.

column45:
Nitro Racing is a high-speed motorsport event where teams build and race remote-controlled cars powered by internal combustion engines. Held on an off-road dirt track, the competition tests mechanical design, fuel optimization, control systems, and driving skills. The goal is to complete all laps in the shortest time while ensuring safety and reliability.

Guidelines:

  • Teams of 2–6 members can participate.
  • Cars must be powered exclusively by IC engines (max 4.6cc) using nitro fuel.
  • Manual control via a 2.4 GHz remote is mandatory; autonomous systems are not allowed.
  • Emphasis is on safety, stability, and efficient racing.

Format:

  • Type: Off-road dirt track racing with manual control.
  • Objective: Build and drive a fast, robust, and well-controlled car to finish laps quickly.

Eligibility:

  • Open to students and enthusiasts with knowledge of mechanical design, engine tuning, and electronics.
  • Inter-college teams allowed; each participant can join only one team.

Key Rules:

  • Inter-college teams allowed; each participant can join only one team.
  • Cars must meet size and fuel specifications as per the rulebook.
  • Early starts, off-track movement, and collisions will result in penalties.
  • Judges’ decisions are final.

Scoring:

  • Teams are evaluated based on lap time, driving efficiency, car durability, and innovation.

Judging Criteria:

  • Time Taken: Lower times rank higher.
  • Efficiency: Smooth handling and optimal driving rewarded.
  • Robustness: Cars must withstand race conditions.
  • Innovation: Creative designs or fuel strategies gain extra points.

General Rules:

  • Loose parts on the track lead to disqualification.
  • Judges’ decisions are final.
  • Only volunteers can reposition cars during the race.
  • Mis-behavior will result in disqualification.
  • Organizers may update rules and will inform teams accordingly.

column11: The LNM Institute of Information Technology
column45:
RoboCup is an action-packed robotics event inspired by soccer. Participants build robots to compete in a soccer-style game. This event focuses on programming, control systems, and teamwork to dominate the field and score goals.

Guidelines:

  • Teams of 2-4 participants compete in this two-round event.
  • Robots must be programmed to detect, control, and pass the ball autonomously or semi-autonomously.
  • Matches will follow standard RoboCup rules with some event-specific modifications.

Format:

  • Simulation Type: Robot soccer match.
  • Objective: To score the most goals within the match duration.

Rules:

  • Eligibility: Open to students with robotics and programming experience.
  • Team Size: Teams of 2-4 members.
  • Gameplay:
    • Robots must stay within size limits: Max dimensions: 350 mm x 300 mm x 200 mm (Length x Breadth x Height)
    • Matches will be played on a standard-sized RoboCup arena.
    • Teams must ensure their robots adhere to fair play and avoid physical damage to opponents.

Judging Criteria:

  • Goals scored during matches.
  • Strategy and teamwork demonstrated in gameplay.
  • Robot design and innovation.

column11: The LNM Institute of Information technology
column45:
Roborace is a robotics challenge where teams design manually operated bots to tackle a challenging obstacle course. This event emphasizes innovative design, precise control, and speed as participants compete to conquer rugged terrain and complete tasks efficiently.

Guidelines:

  • Teams of 2-4 participants compete in this event.
  • Bots must be self-designed and comply with specific size and weight limitations.
  • The event involves navigating a challenging obstacle course and completing tasks like maneuvering through tight spaces or overcoming hurdles.

Format:

  • Simulation Type: Obstacle based course involving multiple checkpoints.
  • Objective: To complete the course by obtaining maximum points and in minimum time.

Rules:

  • The dimensions of the bot should be less than or equal to 30 cm × 25 cm × 25 cm (l×b×h) failing which the team will be disqualified from th e competition (this includes tyres). An error of (±5%) is permitted. The dimensions of the remote are not included in the size constraint of the bot.
  • The bot must be controlled manually only by one person, irrespective of the mechanism used.
  • Both wired and wireless control options are available to teams. In the case of wired bots, the wire length should be at least 2 meters to ensure that the cable remains slack at all times. Participants should use a dual- frequency remote, Bluetooth, or Wi-Fi if they employ wireless technologies.
  • The bot must have an onboard power supply case for wireless usage.
  • Participants are not permitted to use any prefabricated Lego parts or grasping   Participants may, however, use pre-assembled gear assemblies.

Judging Criteria:

  • Points scored by completing checkpoints. Penalties and time bonuses also apply.
  • Teams need to score the maximum amount of points. In case of tie breaker, time taken by the bot will be considered.
  • The decision of the judges will be final and will not be subjected to any argument.

column45:
Moto Boat is a water-based robotics challenge where teams build motor-powered boats to complete tasks or race on a water course. This event emphasizes mechanical design, speed, and control.

Guidelines:

  • Teams of 2-4 participants compete in this two-round event.
  • Boats must be self-designed and adhere to size and weight constraints.
  • The event involves completing a water course or performing tasks like object retrieval.

Format:

  • Simulation Type: Motor-powered boat racing or task performance.
  • Objective: To complete the course or tasks in the shortest time.

Rules:

  • The robot must totally fit into a 400mm(length) x 200mm(width) x 200mm(height) cuboid i.e the robot should strictly be smaller than a cuboid of the given dimensions.
  • No external manual control during tasks; all operations must be through onboard systems or RC.
  • Safety measures must be followed to prevent water pollution or accidents.

Judging Criteria:

  • Speed and precision during tasks.
  • Innovation in boat design.
  • Completion of all tasks with minimal penalties.

Round Details:

  • Round 1 (Final) :
  • Date: Plinth - Day1 - Day 2
  • Gameplay: There is only one round, which will be conducted on the first and second days of Plinth.

Team Size:

  • Team participation: 3 members comprising a team.

column45:
Robo Transporter is a robotics-based event that challenges participants to design and build autonomous or manually controlled robots capable of transporting objects through a dynamic course. Teams will compete to complete the course in the shortest time while adhering to the rules. This event tests engineering, programming, and strategic planning skills.

Guidelines:

  • Participants must compete in teams of 2-5.
  • The bot must have an on board power supply.
  • The robot must meet specific size and weight constraints (details below).
  • The event consists of a single round(2 attempts) where teams attempt to transport objects across obstacles.
  • Scoring is based on successful object delivery, time taken, and adherence to the rules.

Format:

  • Simulation Type: Object transportation through a robotic platform.
  • Objective: To design a robot capable of efficiently transporting objects through a challenging course.

Rules:

  • Eligibility: Open to robotics enthusiasts with knowledge of autonomous systems and mechanical design.
  • Team Size: Teams of 2-5 members.
  • Gameplay:
    • Robots must transport objects from the start zone to the target zone.
    • Points are awarded for each successful delivery.
    • Penalties will be given for rule violations or course deviations.
    • Teams have a limited time to complete the course(25min).
    • The robot must remain within size constraints: Max dimensions [30*30*20]cm.

Judging Criteria:

  • Speed: Time taken to complete the course.
  • Precision: Accuracy in delivering objects to the designated area.

column45:
RC Plane is a thrilling event where participants showcase their skills in designing, building, and controlling remote-controlled planes. The challenge includes performing aerial maneuvers and completing specific tasks.

Guidelines:

  • Teams of 2-3 participants compete in this event.
  • The plane must be entirely built or significantly modified by the team.
  • The event includes performance tasks such as loops, rolls, and precision landings.

Format:

  • Simulation Type: Remote-controlled aerial task performance.
  • Objective: To complete as many tasks as possible within the allotted time.

Rules:

  • Planes must adhere to safety regulations and size/weight constraints: Max wingspan 150 cm, weight of RC Plane should be between 900 gm to 2 Kg.
  • Each team gets 2 attempts, with the best performance considered for scoring.

Judging Criteria:

  • Precision in task completion.
  • Creativity and efficiency of the plane’s design.
  • Safety and control during the flight.

column45:
Micromouse is an exciting robotics event where participants design and program autonomous robots to navigate a complex maze. The objective is to find the shortest path from the starting point to the goal in the least time. This event challenges participants’ algorithmic skills, sensor integration, and optimization techniques.

Guidelines:

  • Teams of 1-3 participants can compete in this single-round event.
  • Robots must autonomously navigate the maze without any manual intervention.
  • Scoring is based on the time taken to complete the maze and the accuracy of the path.

Format:

  • Simulation Type: Autonomous maze-solving.
  • Objective: To program a robot capable of efficiently navigating a maze to reach the endpoint.

Rules:

  • Eligibility: Open to robotics enthusiasts with knowledge of algorithm development and microcontroller programming.
  • Team Size: Teams of 1-3 members.
  • Gameplay:
    • Robots must adhere to size constraints: Maximum dimensions [18 cm in length and width; height has no restrictions
    • The maze layout will be revealed shortly before the event begins.
    • Robots can attempt multiple runs, with the best time being considered for scoring.
    • External control or intervention during the run is prohibited.

Judging Criteria:

  • Time Taken: Shorter times will score higher.
  • Path Optimization: Efficient pathfinding algorithms are rewarded.
  • Innovation: Creative and effective robot designs will gain additional points.

column45:
Tech Expo is an exhibition-style event where participants display their innovative tech projects and prototypes. This event is an excellent opportunity to showcase creativity, engineering skills, and the application of emerging technologies.

Guidelines:

  • Teams of 1-4 participants can exhibit projects.
  • Projects can span any technology domain: robotics, AI/ML, IoT, etc.
  • Teams must prepare a brief presentation or demonstration of their project.

Format:

  • Simulation Type: Tech project demonstration.
  • Objective: To display innovative and impactful technological solutions.

Rules:

  • Projects must be original and created by the team.
  • Each team will get a fixed presentation time: [Insert Time Limit].
  • Teams must adhere to safety guidelines during demonstrations.

Judging Criteria:

  • Innovation and impact of the project.
  • Clarity and effectiveness of the presentation.
  • Feasibility and real-world applicability.

column45:
The National Commerce Olympiad, conducted by The Commerce Society of Shri Ram College of Commerce (SRCC), is a nationwide competition that evaluates students' expertise in commerce concepts, analytical thinking, and problem-solving.  The National Commerce Olympiad is a prestigious platform designed to challenge and celebrate young minds.

This is the perfect opportunity to test your limits, refine your skills, and push yourself beyond your comfort zone. Seize this unparalleled opportunity to showcase your knowledge and compete for a prize pool worth 1,00,000 in cash and kind.

What are you waiting for? Register for the National Commerce Olympiad today and unlock an exciting adventure of learning, discovery, and incredible rewards!

Eligibility:

  • Open to students currently enrolled in Class XI or Class XII.
  • The Olympiad will be conducted online on 4th of January, 2026.

Procedure for Individual Registration:

  • Click on 'Register on Unstop' to begin the registration process.
  • Log in using your Facebook, Google, or LinkedIn account, or create a new account on Unstop.
  • Fill in your details, including your name, school, class, and other personal credentials. Ensure to mention your Aadhar Card Number, City, and State. The Olympiad is open to students from all streams currently studying in classes XI and XII. Once completed, click 'Submit.'
  • Select a payment method and proceed to pay the registration fee by clicking on 'Pay.'
  • On making the payment, you will get a payment confirmation email.

Note: Details regarding the platform and login credentials will be sent to the registered candidates via email a few days prior to the examination.

Structure of the Olympiad:

The Olympiad is designed to evaluate students across multiple domains, featuring sections on:

  • Verbal Ability
  • Logical Reasoning/Quantitative Aptitude/Data Interpretation
  • Economics/Mathematics
  • Business Studies/Accountancy
  • Case Studies and Problem-Solving

Separate Olympiads will be conducted for Class 11 and Class 12, each comprising 60 questions to be attempted within 60 minutes.

Marking Scheme:

  • +4 marks for every correct answer
  • -1 mark for every incorrect answer
  • 0 marks for unattempted questions

About the Institution:

Shri Ram College of Commerce (SRCC), India’s No.1 Commerce college, is a leader in commerce and economics education. Known for its academic excellence and vibrant extracurriculars, SRCC attracts the nation’s brightest young minds.

The Commerce Society, one of SRCC’s six registered societies, has been Delhi University’s top commerce society for four years. With a 50-year legacy, it fosters innovation, creativity, and intellectual growth, preparing students to excel in real-world challenges.

What’s at Stake:

  • Prizes Worth 1,00,000: Winners will take home a combined total of 1,00,000 in cash and kind prizes.
  • Certificates of Merit: All finalists will be honored with certificates of merit.
  • Participation Certificates: Every participant will be awarded a certificate of participation, acknowledging their effort and enthusiasm.
  • CUET Preparation Advantage: The Olympiad follows the CUET pattern, offering participants a valuable opportunity to enhance their preparation for the exam.

column45:
Introduction:

  • Challenge your friends and test your skills in an exciting head-to-head coding battle. In CP Duels, it’s you against your opponent in a thrilling race against time. Solve challenging problems, outthink, and outcode your competitor to claim victory.
  • Every second counts as you tackle complex coding tasks designed to push your competitive programming abilities to the limit. It's a test of speed, logic, and focus—debug faster, think smarter, and prove you have what it takes to emerge as the ultimate coder.
  • Are you ready to take on the challenge? Let the duels begin!

Guidelines:

  • Guidelines will be shared on the day of the event.

Rules:

  • Rules will be shared on the day of the event.

Judging Criteria:

  • In a duel, the person who solves the given problem first wins and incorrect submissions are not taken into account.

Round Details:

  • Round 1:
    • Date: Plinth - All 3 days of Plinth
    • Gameplay: CP Duels will be conducted on all three days of the Plinth.

Team Size:

  • Individual participation (one participant per registration).

Event Organizers Contact Details

  • For any questions, please reach out to 8295912631, 7018268812.
  • For any questions, please reach out to the Club team at cybrosclub@lnmiit.ac.in.
  • Social Media: Follow @cybros_lnmiit on Instagram for updates and hints.

column11: The LNM Institute of Information Technology
column45:
Introduction:

Cybros proudly presents its flagship individual coding competition, a Division 2-style contest tailored to challenge and motivate participants. This two-hour event invites skilled coders to compete solo, showcasing their problem-solving abilities and technical expertise.

With an impressive prize pool at stake, the contest promises an engaging and high-stakes experience. Participants will have the opportunity to test their skills, push their boundaries, and achieve excellence in a competitive yet inspiring environment.

Join us for this remarkable event and seize the chance to prove your mettle. Let the spirit of coding excellence prevail as the best coder rises to the top!

Guidelines;

  • The contest will run for 2 hours and feature 6 problems to solve.
  • Participation is individual; team entries are not allowed.
  • A 10-minute penalty will be added for every incorrect submission.

Rules:

  • The contest will run for 2 hours and feature approximately 6 problems to solve.
  • Participation is individual; team entries are not allowed.
  • A 10-minute penalty will be added for every incorrect submission.
  • Any participant found engaging in cheating or unfair practices will be immediately disqualified from the contest.
  • VS Studio Editor will be provided during the contest, and participants may add extensions to it as per their convenience.
  • Participants are not allowed to use their own laptops during the contest.
  • The organizers reserve the right to disqualify any participant found violating the rules or engaging in misconduct.

Judging Criteria:

  • Individuals will be judged based on the number of problems they have solved and the total penalty incurred.
  • Individuals that solve more problems with less penalty time will rank higher in the standings.

Round Details:

Round 1: Date: Plinth - Day 3
Gameplay: There is only one round which will be conducted on the third day of Plinth.

Team Size:

  • Individual participation (one participant per registration)
  • Event Organizers Contact Details
    • For any questions, please reach out to 8295912631, 7018268812.
    • For any questions, please reach out to the Club team at cybrosclub@lnmiit.ac.in.
    • Social Media: Follow @cybros_lnmiit on Instagram for updates and hints.

column45:
VentureX

VentureX is the flagship entrepreneurship challenge under Strategia ’26, hosted by Loyola College. Designed in a Shark Tank–style format, it provides budding entrepreneurs and innovators a platform to pitch their business ideas before industry leaders, investors, and venture capitalists.
The event simulates the high-stakes environment of startup funding, testing participants’ creativity, business acumen, and persuasion skills.

Important: Teams can apply for only one competition under the Strategia ’26 event. Multiple entries across different competitions will not be permitted.

Registration & Payment

All participants must pay 300 on the Loyola College website after registering on Unstop.
This payment is compulsory to confirm your participation in Strategia ’26.
The Strategia team will share the payment link and detailed instructions through participants’ registered email IDs.

Structure & Rounds

Online Round 1: Pitch Deck Submission

  • Teams must submit an 8-slide business deck outlining their idea.

  • Submission Deadline: 11:59 PM, December 31, 2025.

  • Qualified teams will advance to Round 2.

  • Shortlisted teams must confirm participation by paying the registration fee.

  • Teams not selected may register for other Strategia ’26 events, subject to slot availability.

Day 1 – Round 2: Live Pitching

  • Teams pitch their business ideas directly to a panel of judges.

  • Time Limit: 6 minutes presentation + 3 minutes Q&A.

  • Judges assess based on innovation, feasibility, scalability, and clarity of communication.

  • The best teams will qualify for Demo Day.

Day 2 – Demo Day

  • Finalists present their Minimum Viable Products (MVPs) to investors, venture capitalists, and industry experts.

  • The Top 2 teams will qualify for the Final Showdown of Strategia ’26.

Rules & Guidelines

  • Participants must register on the Strategia website for the preliminary round.

  • No registration fee is required for the initial pitch deck submission.

  • Teams must adhere strictly to submission deadlines and presentation time limits.

  • Any malpractice or plagiarism will lead to disqualification.

  • The decision of judges and organizers will be final and binding.

Why Participate?

VentureX gives aspiring entrepreneurs the perfect launchpad to turn their ideas into reality. Participants receive constructive feedback from investors, network with industry professionals, and showcase their business concepts before an expert audience.
It’s an unparalleled opportunity to transform innovative ideas into viable ventures and make an impact in the startup ecosystem.

column45:
Market Masters

Market Masters is an engaging trading and advisory challenge under Strategia ’26, hosted by Loyola College. It offers participants a unique platform to showcase their expertise in live market simulations and portfolio management. The competition replicates real-world financial scenarios, testing participants’ decision-making, analytical ability, and presentation skills.

Important: Teams can apply for only one competition under the Strategia ’26 event. Multiple entries across different competitions will not be permitted.

Registration & Payment

All participants must pay 300 on the Loyola College website after registering on Unstop.
This payment is compulsory to confirm participation in Strategia ’26.
The Strategia team will share the payment link and detailed instructions via participants’ registered email IDs.

Guidelines

  • Teams must bring laptops, calculators, and other essentials.

  • Any form of malpractice (e.g., using external funds, deleting trades, etc.) will lead to immediate disqualification.

  • Teams must adhere strictly to presentation time limits and event rules.

Format

Day 1 – Round 1: Virtual Trading

  • Teams will receive virtual capital via a simulation app.

  • Trading session: From 10:00 a.m. until market close.

  • Rankings will be based on net portfolio returns.

  • Qualified teams will proceed to Round 2 and be assigned a financial persona (e.g., young professional, mid-career investor, retiree).

Day 2 – Round 2: Portfolio Management

  • Teams will prepare overnight to design a portfolio using any asset class suited to their assigned persona.

  • Presentation: 7 minutes + 3 minutes Q&A.

  • The Top 2 teams will qualify for the Final Showdown of Strategia ’26.

Rules

  • Teams must follow ethical trading practices throughout the event.

  • Only registered team members are allowed to participate.

  • The decision of the judges and organizers will be final and binding.

column45:
StrategIQ

StrategIQ is an exciting quiz competition designed to test participants’ knowledge of business, finance, and general awareness. The event progresses through multiple challenging rounds and culminates in an intense live buzzer finale to determine the winners.

Important: Teams can apply for only one competition under the Strategia ’26 event. Multiple entries across different competitions will not be permitted.

Registration & Payment

All participants must pay 300 on the Loyola College website after registering on Unstop.
This payment is compulsory to confirm your participation in Strategia ’26.
The Strategia team will share the payment link and detailed instructions through participants’ registered email IDs.

Rules and Guidelines

  • All rounds will be conducted offline at the Loyola College campus.

  • Teams must adhere to the time limits set for each round.

  • All decisions made by the judges and organizers will be final and binding.

Event Structure

Day 1 – Round 1: Written Quiz

  • A one-hour written quiz covering topics from finance, business, and general knowledge.

  • Qualified teams from this round will proceed to Round 2.

Day 1 – Round 2: Strategic Justification

  • Teams will be presented with a strategic scenario containing multiple options.

  • Each team must select a pathway and present their justification to the panel.

  • Evaluation will be based on the choice of option, quality of reasoning, and clarity of communication.

  • Qualified teams will move forward to Round 3.

Day 2 – Round 3: Buzzer Round Finale

  • A live buzzer quiz featuring exciting formats such as rapid fire, connections, and more.

  • Scores will be displayed on a leaderboard, and the team with the highest score will be declared the winner.

  • The Top 2 teams will qualify for the Final Showdown of Strategia ’26.

column45:
Case Quest

Case Quest is the flagship consulting challenge of Strategia ’26, hosted by Loyola College. It tests participants’ ability to analyze complex business problems, devise structured solutions, and deliver impactful presentations before an expert jury. This event mirrors real world consulting assignments, offering students a platform to showcase their strategic thinking, teamwork, and communication skills.

Important: Teams can apply for only one competition under the Strategia ’26 event. Multiple entries across different competitions will not be permitted.

Registration & Payment

All participants must pay 300 on the Loyola College website after registering on Unstop. This payment is compulsory to confirm your participation in Strategia ’26.
The Strategia team will share the payment link and detailed instructions through participants’ registered email IDs.

Structure & Rounds

Day 1 – Round 1: Preliminary Case Submission

  • The case study will be released on the spot at the beginning of the event.

  • Teams must work within the campus to prepare and submit their preliminary deck by 2:00 PM.

  • Shortlisted teams will receive the final case study by 5:00 PM for overnight preparation.

  • Teams must prepare their final deck overnight and submit it before the start of Day 2.

Day 2 – Round 2: Final Presentations

  • Teams present their solutions to a closed panel of judges, ensuring fairness and confidentiality.

  • Time Limit: 7 minutes presentation + 5 minutes Q&A.

  • Judges evaluate based on problem analysis, creativity, feasibility, and clarity.

  • The Top 2 teams secure their ticket to the Final Showdown.

Rules & Guidelines

  • Teams must bring laptops, calculators, and other essentials.

  • Internet facilities will be provided during the event.

  • All submissions and presentations must be original and solely prepared by the team.

  • Teams must adhere strictly to submission and presentation timelines.

  • The decision of the judges and organizers will be final.

Why Participate?

Case Quest offers students a hands-on experience of the real-world consulting process, from analyzing a case under time pressure to presenting actionable solutions before industry experts.
It is the ideal platform for those aspiring to careers in consulting, strategy, or management, helping participants refine their analytical, collaborative, and communication skills.

column11: The LNM Institute of Information Technology
column45:
Team Size:

  • Team participation : 3 members comprising a team.

Introduction:

Have you ever wondered what it feels like to participate in the renowned onsite ICPC contest? If not, Cybros is here to bring that exhilarating experience to you! Presenting an ICPC-style programming contest, this high-energy event challenges teams of three to engage in a rigorous five-hour problem-solving battle.

Put your coding expertise, teamwork, and strategic thinking to the test as you tackle a series of demanding problems designed to push your abilities to their limits. This is more than just a contest—it’s an opportunity to experience the thrill, intensity, and collaboration that define the ICPC spirit.

Join us for a memorable journey where strategy leads to success, collaboration drives innovation, and your skills take center stage. Get ready to compete, conquer, and showcase your potential in this ultimate test of technical excellence!

Guidelines:

  • A 5-hour ICPC-style programming contest featuring approximately 10 to 13 challenging problems.
  • Each team must consist of exactly three members.
  • A standard penalty of 10 minutes will be added for every incorrect submission.
  • A standard 1-hour scoreboard freeze will occur before the contest ends, keeping the final standings a suspenseful reveal.

Rules:

  • The contest will run for 5 hours and feature approximately 10 to 13 challenging problems.
  • Each team must comprise exactly three members.
  • A 10-minute penalty will be added for every incorrect submission.
  • The scoreboard will be frozen for the final 1 hour of the contest to maintain suspense before the standings are revealed.
  • Teams will receive balloons attached to their desks upon successfully solving problems, enhancing the competition’s excitement.
  • Any team found engaging in cheating or unfair practices will be immediately disqualified from the contest.
  • VS Studio Editor will be provided during the contest, and participants may add extensions to it as per their convenience.
  • Participants are not allowed to use their own laptops during the contest.
  • The organizers reserve the right to disqualify any team found violating the rules or engaging in misconduct.

Judging Criteria:

  • Teams will be judged based on the number of problems they have solved and the total penalty incurred.
  • Teams that solve more problems with less penalty time will rank higher in the standings.

Event Organizers Contact Details

  • For any questions, please reach out to 8295912631, 7018268812.
  • For any questions, please reach out to the Club team at cybrosclub@lnmiit.ac.in.
  • Social Media: Follow @cybros_lnmiit on Instagram for updates and hints.

column11: The LNM Institute of Information Technology
column45:
Introduction:

Robowars is an action-packed robotics battle where teams design and operate combat robots to face off in a high-intensity arena. The event tests creativity, control, durability, and combat strategy. Teams compete in one-on-one or rumble-style matches, aiming to disable or outmaneuver opponents while ensuring safety and fair play.

Guidelines:

  • Teams of 2 or more members can participate. At least one member must be an adult.
  • Robots must be powered by onboard batteries; no IC engines are allowed.
  • Manual control via wireless remote is mandatory, with emergency stop functions for safety.
  • Aggression, control, and damage management are key to scoring and victory.

Format & Objective:

  • Type: One-on-one or rumble matches in a fully enclosed arena.
  • Objective: Build a combat-ready robot that can outfight opponents through strategy, mobility, and resilience.

Key Rules:

  • Maximum robot weight: 8kg; dimensions are unrestricted.
  • Pneumatic, hydraulic, and electric lifters are allowed with safety certifications.
  • Spinning weapons must stop safely within 60 seconds after power cut.
  • Robots must avoid flying mechanisms and unsafe designs.
  • Early termination, disqualification, and arena ejection rules apply.
  • Decisions by judges are final and binding.

Scoring:

Robots are judged on:

  • Aggression: Effective and deliberate attacks.
  • Control: Precision in targeting and minimizing damage.
  • Damage: Impact on opponent’s functionality and defenses.

Safety & Fair Play:

  • All power systems must be onboard and safely enclosed.
  • Emergency stop functions are mandatory.
  • No flame weapons beyond permitted fuel limits.
  • Robots must avoid projectiles and harmful devices

column11: The LNM Institute of Information Technology
column45:
Introduction:

Rev your engines and ready your rockets — Smash Karts @ Plinth 2026 is here! This high-octane battle-arena racing game combines speed, chaos, and pure fun. Outdrive and outgun your opponents in intense multiplayer matches to become the ultimate kart champion of LNMIIT’s tech and gaming fest.

  • Whether you’re drifting through online qualifiers or blasting your way through the LAN finals, every second counts — drive smart, shoot sharp, and survive to win!

Participation Rules:

  • Event Type: Solo (1 player per entry)
  • Eligibility: Open to all school and college students
  • Mode: Online
  • Platform: Browser-based 
  • Players must use their own Smash Karts account or guest ID.
  • Custom private lobbies will be created by event moderators.
  • Fair play is mandatory — use of scripts, mods, or unauthorized tools will result in immediate disqualification.
  • Players must ensure a stable internet connection during online rounds.
  • No external controllers or devices that provide unfair advantage are allowed.

Competition Flow:

  • Round 1: Online Qualifiers
    • Mode: Online (via Unstop + SmashKarts.io custom lobbies)
    • Format: Group-based free-for-all
    • Top players from each group advance to Round 2.
  • Round 2: Knockout Stage
    • Mode: Online
    • Format: Multiple heats of Free-for-All
    • Top scorers proceed to Quarter Finals.
  • Round 3: Quarter Finals
    • Mode: Online
    • Format: 3-round point-based matches
    • Top 8 racers advance to Semi-Finals.
  • Round 4: Semi-Finals
    • Mode: Online
    • Format: 3-round series; cumulative points decide finalists.
  • Round 5: Grand Finale
    • Mode: Online
    • Format: 5-round series — the racer with the highest total score becomes the Smash Karts Champion.

column11: The LNM Institute of Information Technology
column45:
Introduction:

  • Step into the arena with Plinth Clash Royale, the ultimate Clash Royale showdown of Plinth 2026. Test your strategy, reflexes, and decision-making against the best players across the nation. Whether you’re a seasoned Royale veteran or a rising challenger, this is your chance to prove your mastery and climb to the top of the tower!

Participation Rules:

  • Event Type: Individual (1v1 battles)
  • Eligibility: Open to all school and college students.
  • Mode: Both Online and Offline (On-campus at LNMIIT Jaipur).
  • Each participant must use their own Clash Royale account.
  • Fair play is mandatory — use of third-party software, account sharing, or cheating will result in immediate disqualification.
  • Players must ensure a stable internet connection during online rounds.

Competition Flow:

  • Round 1: Online Qualifiers
    • Mode: Online (via Unstop + Clash Royale)
    • Date: Before Plinth 2026
    • Format: Players will be grouped into online brackets.
    • Top-performing players advance to Round 2.
  • Round 2: Knockout Stage
    • Mode: Online
    • Format: 1v1 elimination matches (Best of 3)
    • Winners proceed to the next stage.
  • Round 3: Semi-Finals
    • Mode: Offline @ LNMIIT Jaipur
    • Format: Best of 3 matches
    • Semi-finalists will battle live at the campus gaming zone.
  • Round 4: Grand Finale
    • Mode: Offline @ LNMIIT Jaipur
    • Format: Best of 5 matches
    • Finalists face off in front of a live audience for the title of Plinth Clash Royale Champion.

column2: Cryptex : The Online Treasure Hunt Challenge
column45:
There is no giveaway of Free Fire Coupons !! 

Guidelines

  • Each participant must register individually to compete.
  • The quiz is set up in levels, where players must solve one question to advance to the next.
  • Participants can utilize online resources, but each level is more challenging than the last.
  • Follow Quizzinga on Instagram @quizzingalnm for hints and updates.

Rules

  • Eligibility: Open to anyone interested.
  • Duration: Cryptex 2026 runs live for three days.
  • Levels: There are 30 levels, each increasing in complexity.
  • Progression: Correctly answering each question unlocks the next level.
  • Hints: Provided on the Quizzinga Instagram page.
  • Googling: Permitted, though questions are crafted to challenge your search skills.
  • Answer Sharing: Participants should avoid sharing answers to maintain fairness.
  • Disqualification: Posting answers on social media will result in disqualification.
  • Discrepancies: The quizmaster’s decision will be final.
  • Updates: Rules may change; participants will be notified via email.

Judging Criteria

Participants will be judged based on their ability to successfully complete all levels. The fastest to complete all levels, with accuracy, will be crowned the winner.

Round Details

Round 1: Gameplay: There is only one and final round. It will last 3 days.

Team Size

  • Individual participation (one participant per registration).

column11: The LNM Institute of Information Technology
column45:
Overview:

  • The Ideathon at Plinth 2026 is designed for early-stage innovators—even those with just an idea can participate.
  • This is your platform to showcase creativity, share solutions, and test your entrepreneurial spark in front of experts.
  • It’s less about polished startups and more about big thinking, fresh ideas, and pitching potential.

Guidelines:

  • Team size: Minimum 1 member, Maximum 4 members
  • Open to students from all institutions
  • Ideas can be from any domain—technology, healthcare, sustainability, education, finance, agriculture, logistics, social impact, or consumer products
  • Round 1 is online via Unstop; Round 2 is offline at LNMIIT Jaipur
  • Presentations should be concise and within the allotted time
  • The decision of the judging panel is final and binding

Round 1: Idea Submission (via Unstop):

  • Participants submit a pitch deck (max 6–7 slides) describing their idea
  • No prototype or advanced model required—raw innovative ideas are welcome
  • Submissions will be evaluated on originality, clarity, and problem-solving potential
  • Shortlisted entries move to the on-campus finale
  • Start: December 1
  • End: Before Day 1

Round 2: Grand Finale (Offline @ LNMIIT Jaipur):

  • Shortlisted teams present their ideas live in an LT at LNMIIT
  • Each team will have 7 minutes to pitch followed by a 3-minute Q&A
  • Judging will be based on creativity, practicality, presentation, and handling of questions
  • Start: Day 1
  • End: Day 1

column45:
EDV26 – ESCAPE DA-VINCI is a one-of-a-kind gamified vibe coding hackathon combining coding, puzzles, and creativity. Participants step into an escape room–style adventure, where they must unlock codes, debug problems, and build prototypes to progress through each stage.
The journey culminates in the Final Trophy Unlock, where only the sharpest minds triumph.

Event Overview

  • Beginner-friendly yet challenging for experienced participants
  • Fusion of coding, design, puzzles, and prototyping
  • Escape Room Format: Teams will be locked inside themed rooms; each round begins with a coded lock/problem. Solving it unlocks the challenge and grants access to the next stage
  • Online eliminations + 36-hour Offline Finale

Event Flow:

Online Rounds (5th November 2025 - 5th January 2026)

  • Round 1 – PPT / Video Submission
    • Submission: 8-slide PPT or 3–5 min video (template provided)
    • Tracks: AI/ML, Web/App, Robotics, Art/Design, Cryptography(submit any best project of yours on any problem statements following the given tracks).
    • Platform: Unstop
    • Outcome: Shortlisted teams qualify for Online Round 2
  • Round 2 – Website / Model Deployment
    • Task: Deploy a working project/model online
    • Platform: Unstop
    • Outcome: Top teams qualify for the Offline Hackathon

Offline Hackathon (21st –22nd January 2026 | 36 Hours)

The offline adventure follows a Da Vinci escape-room inspired format. Teams will be locked in rooms and must unlock challenges stage by stage:

  • Round 1 (3 hrs): Debug spectogram/code → unlock problem
  • Round 2 (3 hrs): Rapid prototype (AI/Tech-based)
  • Round 3 (2 hrs): Fun + Brainy Challenges (Puzzle / AR / Meme-based)
  • Round 4 (4 hrs): Final Spectogram & Trophy Unlock

Prize Pool:

  • 1st Place: 75,000
  • 2nd Place: 35,000
  • 3rd Place: 20,000
  • Special Awards:
    • Best UI/UX – 5,000
    • Most Fun Project – 5,000
    • Top Newcomer/First-Year Team – 5,000

Grand Prize: 2-ft Trophy + Prize Money

Guidelines

  • Eligibility
    • Open to all students across disciplines and years.
    • Teams of 3–5 members only.
  • Participation Rules
    • Teams must participate in both online rounds to qualify for the offline finale.
    • A minimal confirmation fee will be charged after round 1 to confirm your availability.
    • The offline hackathon will be conducted in escape-room style, where participants will be locked inside themed rooms and must solve challenges to progress.
  • Submission Guidelines
    • Online Round 1: Submit PPT (8 slides) or video (3–5 minutes) in the provided template (submit any best project of yours on any problem statements following the given tracks).
    • Online Round 2: Working website/model deployment with accessible link.
  • Hackathon Conduct
    • You are free to use any AI tool or platform!
    • Respectful conduct with peers, mentors, and organizers is mandatory.
  • Resources
    • Participants must bring their own laptops, chargers, and essential gear.
    • Internet access will be provided during the offline rounds.
    • Additional hardware/tools (if required for prototypes) should be managed by the teams themselves.
  • Finale Guidelines
    • Once locked inside the escape-room challenge, teams must rely on teamwork, skill, and creativity to progress.
    • The Final Round has no shortcuts – only problem-solving and collaboration will lead to the Trophy Unlock.

Why Participate:

  • Experience a real escape-room–themed hackathon
  • Blend of tech, puzzles, and adventure
  • Beginner-friendly yet competitive for pros
  • Build, innovate, and test your problem-solving skills under pressure
  • Win recognition, cash prizes worth 1.45 Lakh, and the Da Vinci Trophy

Registration Details

  • Platform: Unstop
  • Team Size: 3–5 members
  • Eligibility: Open to all students
  • Whatsapp group Link: https://chat.whatsapp.com/Dc4EPMI70gUJwgQxrIa3aE

column45:
The Campus Marketing Challenge (CMC) is a joint initiative by E-Cell VGI and Nerds Room to discover and empower students who can market, influence, and grow communities through creativity.

Ambassadors will complete point-based tasks like social media marketing, outreach, and event promotion, representing both E-Cell VGI and Nerds Room on their campuses. Performance will be tracked on a leaderboard, and top performers will be recognized with exclusive rewards and opportunities.

This is not a formal hiring program—it’s a challenge where your marketing skills, creativity, and influence define your success. The overall challenge duration is 3 months.

Guidelines:

  • Eligibility: Open to all undergraduate & postgraduate students from any college.
  • Team Formation: Only individual participation is allowed (no teams).
  • Inter-college / Inter-specialization: Not applicable as participation is individual.
  • Format:
    • Participants complete weekly marketing tasks (content creation, social media campaigns, referrals, event promotion, etc.).
    • Each task will carry points.
    • A leaderboard will be updated regularly.
  • Number of problem statements: Multiple small tasks instead of a single problem statement.

Rules:

  • Each participant must complete assigned tasks within the given deadline.
  • Plagiarism or fake engagement (bots, fake accounts, etc.) will lead to disqualification.
  • All posts/content must tag E-Cell VGI and Nerds Room official handles where applicable.
  • Respectful communication and professional behavior are mandatory.
  • Leaderboard rankings will be based on points scored from tasks + engagement metrics.

Rewards & Perks:

For All Participants:

  • Certificate of Appreciation from E-Cell VGI & Nerds Room
  • Offer Letter as Campus Marketer

For Top 5 Performers:

  • Exclusive Goodies from E-Cell VGI & Nerds Room
  • Social Media Shoutouts on official pages

For Top 3 Winners:

  • Certificate of Recommendation from E-Cell VGI & Nerds Room
  • Core Team Interview Opportunity
  • Spotlight recognition across platforms

Process Flow:

  • Register on Unstop for the challenge.
  • Join our official WhatsApp/Telegram group for updates.
    https://chat.whatsapp.com/IHkokIfkw13HCkcNwmw0iV?mode=ems_copy_t
  • Weekly tasks will be shared in the group.
  • Submit proofs/screenshots of task completion as per instructions.
  • Leaderboard will be updated weekly.
  • Winners will be announced at the end of the 3-month challenge.

Why Participate?

  • Represent E-Cell VGI and Nerds Room on your campus.
  • Build your marketing & branding portfolio.
  • Get recognized as a student influencer.
  • Win goodies, certificates & offer letters.
  • Chance to work in the Core Team.

column45:
The Polaris Innov-a-thon is a first-of-its-kind hackathon where students get an early exposure to real world problem solving through code and AI.

With a headstart like this in school, the aim is to inculcate a mindset in the students that would enable them to look beyond marks and assignments, and create real world impact. The result will be the beginning of a journey towards becoming the next-gen techpreneurs (tech entrepreneurs) of India.

Why join the Polaris Innov-a-thon?

  • National-level recognition 
  • Scholarship and 1-to-1 access to CTOs of top tech companies
  • 1st-hand Industry and Tech-preneur experience even before college 
  • Early exposure to working in a professional tech environment, solving real-world tech problems
  • FREE Microsoft Certification for all participants

Stages of Innov-a-thon:

  • Level 1 - Intra School Round: Participants will have to battle it out with student coders from their own school. 
  • Level 2 - Inter School State-level Round: The Top 2 student coders from each school across the state will compete to make it to the next level.
  • Level 3 - National-level Grand Finale Round: The final frontier where the best of the best student coders a.k.a the State Winners will face off in the Innov-a-thon Finale, for the ultimate prize.

column45:
About the Event:

  • Arambh is our endeavour to ignite groundbreaking start-ups and innovative ideas, facilitate their transformation into feasible, pragmatic, and actionable solutions, and provide visionaries with a platform and visibility to claim the recognition they rightfully deserve.

Event Structure:

Preliminary Round (Round 1) – Strategy Challenge (Submission by 20th December 2025):

  • Teams must devise a compelling strategy for a start-up within their chosen state.
  • Submissions must include:Business Plan (10 pages max):
    • Vision, mission, market analysis, and financial projections.
    Executive Summary (1 page):
    • Overview of the start-up concept, mission and vision statements, and summary of key financial projections.
    Market Analysis (1–2 pages):
    • Description of target market, market trends and opportunities, and competitive landscape analysis.
    Business Model (1 page):
    • Explanation of revenue generation, pricing strategy, sales, and distribution channels.
    Product or Service Description (1 page):
    • Comprehensive description of the product or service, unique selling points, and advantages.
    Marketing and Sales Strategy (1–2 pages):
    • Marketing plan, sales strategy, customer acquisition, and retention tactics.
    Operational Plan (1–2 pages):
    • Details on business operations, supply chain management, and production/service delivery process.
    Financial Projections (1–2 pages):
    • Sales forecasts, income statements, balance sheets, cash flow projections, and break-even analysis.
    Team (1 page):
    • Profiles of key team members, their roles, and relevant skills and experiences.
  • Video Pitch: Maximum 3 minutes; accepted formats: .wmv, .avi, .flv, .mp4.
  • Poster: Accepted formats: .jpeg or .png, minimum 300 dpi; no specific size requirements.
  • Submission of all three items is mandatory.

Live Round (Round 2) – Pitch Round:

  • Selected teams will deliver a comprehensive investment pitch for their respective state start-up initiatives.
  • Presentations must be created in MS PowerPoint; total presentation time is 30 minutes (20 minutes presentation + 10 minutes Q&A).
  • Pitch Deck (max 10 slides excluding introduction and conclusion):Title Slide: Start-up name, logo, team members’ names and photos.
    Problem Statement: Clearly define the problem the start-up aims to solve.
    Solution: Describe the innovative solution.
    Competitive Landscape/USP: Highlight unique selling points and competitive advantage.
    Market Opportunity: Showcase market size and growth potential.
  • Audience will vote for their favorite pitch using a designated polling platform.
  • Final score is a weighted average of judges’ scores and audience poll.

Evaluation:

  • Panel of 3 Judges (1 University, 2 External)
  • Audience Poll
  • Weightage:
    • Judge 1 (External): 30%
    • Judge 2 (External): 30%
    • Judge 3 (Internal): 20%
    • Audience (Internal): 20%

Timeline:

  • Elimination Round results: 26th December 2025, 11:59:59 PM
  • Final Round (Finale): 9th & 10th January 2026 at SBUP Auditorium
  • Submission deadline: 20th December 2025, 11:59:59 PM via email (arambh@sbup.edu.in)
  • Email subject line format: Team Name_Institute (e.g., Maverick_BIMM)
  • Results will be declared on the spot

Eligibility and Rules:

  • Two categories: Start-ups and Students
  • Teams must mention the category they belong to

Start-ups:

  • Early-stage start-ups that have not received funding exceeding Rs 1 Crore

Students:

  • Currently enrolled in an educational institution (undergraduate or postgraduate)
  • Team size: 2 to 4 members

column45:
Codesta Coding Club proudly presents an exclusive trial coding contest crafted to help members sharpen their programming and analytical thinking. The contest is a perfect opportunity to experience the excitement of competitive coding, where participants must solve algorithmic challenges under time pressure while maintaining accuracy and efficiency. It is not just about solving problems, but about writing clean, optimized, and logical code.

Contest Format

  • Languages Allowed: C, C++, Java, Python
  • Sections:
    • Sec A: 4 Questions (5 marks each)
    • Sec B: 1 Questions (10 marks each)
  • Scoring is based on the number of test cases passed.
  • Multiple submissions are allowed, but only your best attempt will be counted.
  • In case of a tie, the ranking will be decided by the time of last correct submission.

Rules & Guidelines

  • Reporting Time: Flexible – test link remains open til 31st Dec 2025 (23:59). Participants can attempt the contest for 2 hour at any time within this window.
  • Registration is mandatory before the contest begins.
  • No smartphones, smart bands, or smart watches are permitted during the contest.
  • Copy-pasting code is strictly prohibited; participants must write their own solutions.
  • If a participant switches screens more than 3 times, the contest will automatically end.
  • Any cheating, plagiarism, or violation of rules will lead to immediate disqualification and a ban from future Codesta contests.

Note

This contest is purely for practice, learning, and self-improvement. There will be no prizes for ranks, but it is a golden opportunity to test your knowledge, challenge yourself, and gain the real experience of a competitive coding environment.

Main Events:

  • 3x3x3 Cube

    • First Round: Format - Bo2/Ao5, Time Limit - 10m, Cutoff - 2 attempts to get < 6m, Proceed - Top 20.
    • Second Round: Format - Ao5, Time Limit - 10m, Proceed - Top 10.
    • Final Round: Format - Ao5, Time Limit - 10m.

  • 4x4x4 Cube

    • First Round: Format - Bo2/Ao5, Time Limit - 4m, Cutoff - 2 attempts to get < 3m, Proceed - Top 7.
    • Final Round: Format - Ao5, Time Limit - 4m.

Other Events:

  • 2x2x2 Cube

    • Final Round: Format - Ao5, Time Limit - 3m.

  • 5x5x5 Cube

    • Final Round: Format - Bo2/Ao5, Time Limit - 6m, Cutoff - 2 attempts to get < 6m.

  • 3x3x3 Cube (One-Handed)

    • Final Round: Format - Bo2/Ao5, Time Limit - 2m 30s, Cutoff - 2 attempts to get < 2m.

  • 7x7x7 Cube

    • Final Round: Format - Mo3, Time Limit - 10m.

  • Megaminx

    • Final Round: Format - Bo2/Ao5, Time Limit - 5m, Cutoff - 2 attempts to get < 5m.

  • Pyraminx

    • Final Round: Format - Ao5, Time Limit - 2m.

Schedule:

January 23, 2026 (Day 1)

  • 11:40 AM - 1:30 PM: Buffer & New Registration.
  • 1:30 PM - 2:30 PM: Lunch.

January 24, 2026 (Day 2)

  • 11:00 AM: Check-In & Tutorials.
  • 11:40 AM - 12:00 PM: Buffer.

  • 1:00 PM - 1:30 PM: Buffer & New Registration.

  • 5:30 PM - 6:00 PM: Buffer.

January 25, 2026 (Day 3)

  • 11:00 AM: Check-In & Tutorials.
  • 11:30 AM - 12:30 PM: 3x3x3 Cube First Round.
  • 12:30 PM - 1:30 PM: Lunch.
  • 1:30 PM - 3:00 PM: 3x3x3 Cube First Round (Continued).

  • 4:30 PM - 5:30 PM: 3x3x3 Cube Final Round.
  • 6:00 PM - 7:00 PM: Closing Ceremony & Prize Distribution.

column45:
It takes a moment (or an episode, if you’re participating in a reality show) to announce the winner. But that moment is the end of a long road - one that is fraught with strategy-planning meetings, heated discussions, working on original deliverables, and scaling the competition. 

Well, this is your chance to share about your journey and even inspire others to become winners. And when we say want to know about your unstoppable journey, we want every little detail - from arriving at a team name to the ‘eureka’ moment when you were struck with the winning idea. And of course, the experience of being named winners. 

Remember, your experience can very well be the inspiration that another group is looking for to sign up for a competition and get a chance to sing we are the Champions… or whatever else floats their boat.

column45:
Essay writing is an art, which brings out your writing skill. It is an art, through which you pen down your knowledge and perception about the given topic. 

Mononomosumi is an ISO certified and record holder and highly acclaimed noncommercial Edutech Platform, that brings together technology to the education sector and providing requisite support to students, writers, and school administrations. Officially launched in May 2018 with the intent to make writing-related writing extracurricular activities accessible through technology-driven solutions.

It is a monthly International Essay Contest. With a carefully chosen educational topic given once a month, we encourage participants to develop not only the skills of penning down their thoughts but also creativity, research, and organization skills. We believe in the enrichment of society by empowering young individuals with constructive thinking for creating a positive ambiance for overall societal growth.

 Submission Guideline:

  • Deadline: 25th of every month
  • Language: English/Hindi/Bengali
  • Nationality: Any
  • Categories: Two ( Junior & Senior Category) (a) Below 14 years old* (Junior Category) * DOB is must (b) Above 14 years old (Senior Category). There is no upper age limit
  • Registration: No registration required. No fee is required. Submission through only Essay Submission module (click on it)

Important Rules :

  • The essay should be a minimum of 750 words for the senior category and 500 words for the junior category. There is no maximum word count.
  • The submitted essay should be plagiarism-free/have no copy from the internet/unique writing.
  • You can participate every month.
  • Participants are encouraged to write in such a way as to avoid writing "I" or personal experiences unless the topic is such that you are compelled to write your experience.
  • The deadline for submission is the 25th of every month
  • For those participants, who (only those) do not have access to a computer/laptop, they can email (essay.monomousumi@gmail.com) hand-written essays following all the rules mentioned above.  Hand-written essays will not be published but will be eligible for the contest. They are equally eligible but the essay will not be published.  So, if you do not have a computer or laptop, you can just type in mobile in part wise. The handwritten essay should be considered as the last option. 
  • Selected essays will be published on the website with the name, photo, and bio of the participants without the need for prior permission. Sending your essay to us itself gives us the authority to publish it from our side anywhere, online or in digital magazines. However, participants can tell in the very beginning that they are not interested in publishing the article anywhere. 

Results:

The result is declared in the first week of every month through this link and the certificates can be downloaded using this link https://weavermag.com/essay-contest/public/result instantly after the announcement of the result. The certificates will be issued to only the eligible candidates. To see the previous winners, click here!

column45:
Event Title: Corporate Buddha'25 – Case Study Competition
Event Organizers: Think Tank, Genesis 2025-26
Event Dates:

  • Round 1: 29th December 2025
  • Round 2: 5th January 2026
  • Final Round: 10th January 2026

About the Event: 

Think Tank presents Corporate Buddha'25, a prestigious case study competition held during Genesis 2024-25. This competition offers B-School students an opportunity to address real-world business challenges with innovative solutions. The competition will blend classroom knowledge with practical industry problems, enabling participants to apply their learning and gain invaluable experience.

Winners will receive cash prizes up to 45,000.

Event Structure:

  • Round 1:

    • Type: Online Quiz
    • Date: 29th December 2025
    • Time: 6:00 PM

  • Round 2:

    • Submission Deadline: 5th January 2026, 11:59 AM
    • Submission Format:
      • 6-slider deck (excluding title and thank you slides)
      • Deck must not include college logos; the title page should have the team name and participant names.
      • Submit in PPT and PDF formats in a ZIP file with this naming convention: CB'25_TeamName_CollegeName.
    • Issues: Submit by email (thinktank@fsm.ac.in) by 9th December 2024, 11:59 AM if there are any submission issues.

  • Final Round:

    • Date: 10th January 2026
    • Format: Teams will present their case solutions to a panel of corporate leaders.
    • Location: On-campus

Eligibility:

  • Team Size: 2 to 3 members.
  • Participation Limit: No participant should be part of more than one team.

Submission Guidelines:

  • Case Deliverables: Case solution should be original, with all sources of information properly cited.
  • File Naming: Follow the specified naming convention for submission.

Important Notes:

  • Judgment: The decision of the organizers and panel of judges will be final.
  • Citations: All information sources should be properly referenced.
